{{redirect|Moon ring|other uses|Rings Around the Moon (disambiguation)}}
[[File:46 degree Lunar Halo.JPG|thumb|A 22° halo around the Moon]]
A '''22° halo''' is an [[optical phenomenon]] that belongs to the family of ice crystal [[Halo (optical phenomenon)|halos]], in the form of a ring with a radius of approximately 22° around the [[Sun]] or [[Moon]]. When visible around the moon, it is called a moon ring or winter halo. It forms as the sun- or moonlight is [[refraction|refracted]] in millions of [[hexagonal]] [[ice crystal]]s suspended in the atmosphere.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.atoptics.co.uk/halo/circ2.htm|title="Disk with a hole" in the sky|website=www.atoptics.co.uk}}</ref> The halo is large; the radius is roughly the size of an outstretched hand at arm's length.<ref name="atoptics-circular-halo" /> A 22° halo may be visible on as many as 100 days per year—much more frequently than rainbows.<ref name="collector">{{cite book | title=The Cloud Collector's Handbook | publisher=Chronicle Books | author=Pretor-Pinney, Gavin | year=2011 | location=San Francisco, California | pages=120 | isbn=978-0-8118-7542-4}}</ref>
== Formation == [[File:Path of rays in a hexagonal prism.png|left|thumb|Pathway of light through a hexagonal prism in the optimal angle resulting in minimum deviation.]] [[File:22 degree halo Observer looking at 22 degree halo.svg|thumb|upright= 0.65|Path of the light from the clouds to the observer.]]
Even though it is one of the most common types of halo, the exact shape and orientation of the ice crystals responsible for the 22° halo are still the topic of debate. Hexagonal, randomly oriented columns are usually put forward as the most likely candidate, but this explanation presents problems, such as the fact that the aerodynamic properties of such crystals leads them to be oriented horizontally rather than randomly. Alternative explanations include the involvement of clusters of bullet-shaped ice columns.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Tape |first1=Walter |last2=Moilanen |first2=Jarmo |date= |title=Atmospheric Halos and the Search for Angle ''x'' |url= |location=Washington, DC |publisher=American Geophysical Union |page=15 |isbn=0-87590-727-X}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.atoptics.co.uk/fza103.htm |title=Bullet Rosettes & 22° Halos |last=Cowley |first=Les |date=April 2016 |website=Atmospheric Optics | access-date=2016-04-30}}</ref>
As light passes through the 60° apex angle of the hexagonal ice [[prism (optics)|prisms]] it is deflected twice resulting in deviation angles ranging from 22° to 50°. The angle of minimum deviation is almost 22° (or more specifically 21.84° on average; 21.54° for red light and 22.37° for blue light). This wavelength-dependent variation in refraction causes the inner edge of the circle to be reddish while the outer edge is bluish.
The ice crystals in the clouds all deviate the light similarly, but only the ones from the specific ring at 22 degrees contribute to the effect for an observer at a set distance. As no light is refracted at angles smaller than 22°, the sky is darker inside the halo.<ref name="atoptics-circular-halo-formation">{{cite web | url = http://www.atoptics.co.uk/halo/circ1.htm | title = 22° Halo Formation | publisher = Atmospheric Optics | accessdate = 2007-04-15 | author = Les Cowley }} (Including excellent illustrations and animations.)</ref>
Another phenomenon resulting in a ring around the Sun or Moon—and therefore sometimes confused with the 22° halo—is the [[Corona (meteorology)|corona]]. Unlike the 22° halo, however, it is produced by water droplets instead of ice crystals and it is much smaller and more colorful.<ref name="atoptics-circular-halo">{{cite web | url = http://www.atoptics.co.uk/halo/circular.htm | title = 22° Circular halo | publisher = Atmospheric Optics | accessdate = 2007-04-15 | author = Les Cowley
}}</ref>
== Weather relation == In [[folklore]], moon rings are said to warn of approaching storms.<ref name="earthsky">{{cite web|title=Why a halo around the sun or moon?|url=http://earthsky.org/space/what-makes-a-halo-around-the-moon|website=earthsky.org|publisher=EarthSky|accessdate=3 August 2016|quote=Lunar halos are signs that storms are nearby.}}</ref> Like other ice halos, 22° halos appear when the sky is covered by thin [[cirrus cloud|cirrus]] or [[cirrostratus cloud]]s that often come a few days before a large storm front.<ref name="7news">{{cite news | url=http://www.thedenverchannel.com/news/30355738/detail.html | title=Nelson: Ring Around Moon Sign Of Approaching Storm | work=The Denver Channel | date=February 1, 2012 | agency=TheDenverChannel.com | accessdate=February 4, 2012 | author=Harrison, Wayne | location=Denver}}</ref> However, the same clouds can also occur without any associated weather change, making a 22° halo unreliable as a sign of bad weather.

File:22° circular solar halo.jpg|22° circular solar halo seen in [[Kolkata]], [[India]] on 30 April 2016. File:22° degree lunar halo.jpg|22° circular lunar halo seen in [[Edinburgh]], [[Scotland]] on 9 March 2017. File:20180201 Winnipeg Sundog and halo.jpg|22° halo with [[Parhelia (phenomenon)|parhelia]] over [[Winnipeg]], [[Manitoba]], [[Canada]]. </gallery> [[File:Halo Moon.jpg|thumb|Halo Moon - [[Springfield, New South Wales (Central Coast)|Springfield]] NSW - Australia - 27/05/18]]

Of Mexican Descent

$martyr
Look Daggers
The Returners |website = }} '''Alejandro Ocana''', better known by his [[stage name]] '''2Mex''', is a [[rapping|rapper]] from [[Los Angeles, California]].{{cite web|url=http://www.dustedmagazine.com/reviews/465|title=2Mex - Sweat Lodge Infinite|publisher=''Dusted Magazine''|first=Joel|last=Calahan|date=March 9, 2004|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20050209214252/http://www.dustedmagazine.com/reviews/465|archive-date=9 February 2005}} He is a member of [[The Visionaries]] and Of Mexican Descent. He has collaborated with [[underground hip hop]] artists such as [[Jel]], [[Omid Walizadeh|Omid]], [[Thavius Beck]], [[Factor (producer)|Factor]], [[Radioinactive]] and [[Isaiah "Ikey" Owens]]. He is a member of the [[Project Blowed]] crew, and he is affiliated with [[Shape Shifters (band)|Shape Shifters]]. ==History== 2Mex attended the [[Good Life Cafe]] open mic nights in 1993. Around that time, he founded Of Mexican Descent with Xololanxinxo.{{citation needed|date=June 2013}} In 1998, he released his first album with [[The Visionaries]] as well as the first Of Mexican Descent album, and he was featured on the OD ([[Omid Walizadeh|Omid]]) compilation album ''Beneath the Surface''. In 1999, he was featured (with Xololanxinxo as Of Mexican Descent) on the Fat Jack compilation album ''Cater to the DJ'', and he released his first solo album ''Fake It Till You Make It'' as The Mind Clouders with producer Mums the Word. In 2000, he was featured (as a member of the Afterlife Crew) on the Afterlife Records compilation ''Declaration of an Independent''.{{citation needed|date=June 2013}} He then released ''B-Boys in Occupied Mexico'' on Mean Street in 2001.{{cite web|url=http://exclaim.ca/Reviews/HipHop/2mex-b_boys_in_occupied_mexico|title=2Mex - B Boys in Occupied Mexico|publisher=''Exclaim!''|first=Thomas|last=Quinlan|date=December 2001|accessdate=August 13, 2012}} ''Sweat Lodge Infinite'' was released on Temporary Whatever in 2003.{{cite web|url=http://www.prefixmag.com/reviews/2mex/sweat-lodge-infinite/12965/|title=Album Review: 2Mex - Sweat Lodge Infinite|publisher=''Prefix''|first=Mike|last=Krolak|date=October 21, 2003|accessdate=August 13, 2012}}{{cite web|url=http://www.xlr8r.com/reviews/2mex/sweat-lodge-infinite |title=Sweat Lodge Infinite |publisher=''XLR8R'' |first=Dave |last=Segal |date=January 27, 2004 |accessdate=August 13, 2012 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131027075941/http://www.xlr8r.com/reviews/2mex/sweat-lodge-infinite |archivedate=October 27, 2013 |deadurl=yes }}{{cite web|url=http://exclaim.ca/Reviews/HipHop/2mex-sweat_lodge_infinite|title=2Mex - Sweat Lodge Infinite|publisher=''Exclaim!''|first=Thomas|last=Quinlan|date=February 2004|accessdate=August 13, 2012}} The self-titled album, ''2Mex'', was released in 2004.{{cite web|url=http://www.xlr8r.com/reviews/2mex/2mex |title=2Mex |publisher=''XLR8R'' |first=Rachel |last=Swan |date=March 23, 2004 |accessdate=August 13, 2012 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131027214924/http://www.xlr8r.com/reviews/2mex/2mex |archivedate=October 27, 2013 |deadurl=yes }}{{cite web|url=http://exclaim.ca/Reviews/HipHop/2mex-2mex|title=2Mex - 2Mex|publisher=Exclaim!|first=Thomas|last=Quinlan|date=April 2004|accessdate=August 13, 2012}} He released ''My Fanbase Will Destroy You'' on [[Strange Famous Records]] in 2010. It features guest appearances from [[Murs (rapper)|Murs]], [[Prince Po]], [[Busdriver]] and [[Nobody (producer)|Nobody]].{{cite web|url=http://www.urb.com/2010/09/28/2mex-dead-hand-control-and-track-listing/ |title=2Mex – Dead Hand Control and Track Listing (MP3) |publisher=URB |first=Trav |last=Glave |date=September 28, 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110101125740/http://www.urb.com/2010/09/28/2mex-dead-hand-control-and-track-listing/ |archivedate=January 1, 2011 |deadurl=yes }} ==Film== 2Mex is featured in Ava Duvernay's award-winning documentary ''[[This Is the Life (2008 film)|This Is the Life]]'', chronicling the music movement that was birthed at The [[Good Life Cafe]] in [[South Los Angeles|South Central]], Los Angeles. [[File:Experimental area at CERNs Antiproton Decelerator (AD) Hall.jpg|thumb|400px|CERNs AD with the ALPHA, ASACUSA and ATRAP collaborations.]] {{CERNaccelerators}} The '''Antiproton Decelerator''' ('''AD''') is a [[storage ring]] at the [[CERN]] laboratory near [[Geneva]].{{cite web|url=https://home.cern/about/accelerators/antiproton-decelerator|title=The Antiproton Decelerator - CERN|publisher=|accessdate=21 December 2016}} It was built as a successor to the [[Low Energy Antiproton Ring]] (LEAR) and started operation in the year 2000. [[Antiprotons]] are created by impinging a proton beam from the [[Proton Synchrotron]] on a metal target. The AD decelerates the resultant antiprotons to an energy of 5.3 MeV, which are then ejected to one of several connected experiments. ==ELENA== {{Redirect|ELENA|other uses|Elena (disambiguation)}} '''ELENA''' ('''Extra Low ENergy Antiproton''') is a 30 m hexagonal storage ring situated inside the AD complex.https://espace.cern.ch/elena-project/sitepages/home.aspx{{cite journal |last1=Oelert |first1=W. |title=The ELENA Project at CERN |journal=[[Acta Physica Polonica B]] |date=2015 |volume=46 |issue=1 |pages=181 |arxiv=1501.05728 |doi=10.5506/APhysPolB.46.181|bibcode=2015AcPPB..46..181O }} It is designed to further decelerate the antiproton beam to an energy of 0.1 MeV for more precise measurements.{{cite journal|last1=Madsen|first1=N.|title=Antiproton physics in the ELENA era|journal=Phil. Trans. R. Soc. A|volume=376|issue=2116|doi=10.1098/rsta.2017.0278|url=http://rsta.royalsocietypublishing.org/content/376/2116/20170278|bibcode=2018RSPTA.37670278M}} The first beam circulated ELENA on 18 November 2016.{{cite web|url=http://home.cern/cern-people/updates/2016/11/new-ring-slow-down-antimatter|title=A new ring to slow down antimatter - CERN|publisher=|accessdate=21 December 2016}} The ring is expected to be fully operational in 2018. [https://greybook.cern.ch/greybook/experiment/detail?id=AD-8 Grey Book] | [http://base.web.cern.ch/ Website] |} ==ATHENA== {{Redirect|ATHENA|[[ESA]] X-ray space telescope|Advanced Telescope for High Energy Astrophysics|the Greek goddess|Athena|other uses|Athena (disambiguation)}} '''ATHENA''' was an [[antimatter]] research project that took place at the Antiproton Decelerator. In August 2002, it was the first experiment to produce 50,000 low-energy [[antihydrogen]] atoms, as reported in ''[[Nature (journal)|Nature]]''. {{cite press |publisher=[[CERN]] |date=18 September 2002 |url=http://press.cern/press-releases/2002/09/thousands-cold-anti-atoms-produced-cern |title=Thousands of cold anti-atoms produced at CERN }} {{cite journal |last=Amoretti |first=M. |display-authors=etal |collaboration=ATHENA Collaboration |date=2002 |title=Production and detection of cold antihydrogen atoms |journal=[[Nature (journal)|Nature]] |volume=419 |issue=6906 |pages=456–459 |bibcode=2002Natur.419..456A |doi=10.1038/nature01096 |pmid=12368849 }} In 2005, ATHENA was disbanded and many of the former members worked on the subsequent [[#ALPHA|ALPHA experiment]]. ===ATHENA physics=== The ATHENA apparatus comprises four main subsystems: the [[antiproton]] catching trap, the positron accumulator, the antiproton/positron mixing trap, and the antihydrogen annihilation detector. All traps in the experiment are variations on the [[Penning trap]], which uses an axial [[magnetic field]] to transversely confine the charged particles, and a series of hollow cylindrical electrodes to trap them axially (Fig. 1a). The catching and mixing traps are adjacent to each other, and coaxial with a 3 T magnetic field from a superconducting solenoid. The positron accumulator has its own magnetic system, also a solenoid, of 0.14 T. A separate [[cryogenic]] heat exchanger in the bore of the [[superconducting magnet]] cools the catching and mixing traps to about 15 K. The ATHENA apparatus features an open, modular design that allows great experimental flexibility, particularly in introducing large numbers of [[positrons]] into the apparatus. The catching trap slows, traps, cools, and accumulates [[antiprotons]]. To cool antiprotons, the catching trap is first loaded with {{val|3|e=8}} electrons, which cool by synchrotron radiation in the 3 T magnetic field. Typically, the AD delivers {{val|2|e=7}} antiprotons having kinetic energy 5.3 MeV and a pulse duration of 200 ns to the experiment at 100 s intervals. The antiprotons are slowed in a thin foil and trapped using a pulsed [[electric field]]. The antiprotons lose energy and equilibrate with the cold electrons by [[Coulomb interaction]]. The electrons are ejected before mixing the antiprotons with positrons. Each AD shot results in about {{val|3|e=3}} cold antiprotons for interaction experiments. The positron accumulator slows, traps and accumulates positrons emitted from a radioactive source (1.{{val|4|e=9}} Bq Na22). Accumulation for 300 s yields 1.{{val|5|e=8}} positrons, 50% of which are successfully transferred to the mixing trap, where they cool by synchrotron radiation. The mixing trap has the axial potential configuration of a nested Penning trap (Fig. 1b), which permits two plasmas of opposite charge to come into contact. In ATHENA, the spheroidal positron cloud can be characterized by exciting and detecting axial plasma oscillations. Typical conditions are: {{val|7|e=7}} stored positrons, a radius of 2 – 2.5 mm, a length of 32 mm, and a maximum density of 2.{{val|5|e=8|u=cm−3}}. Key to the observations reported here is the [[antihydrogen]] annihilation detector (Fig. 1a), situated coaxially with the mixing region, between the trap outer radius and the magnet bore. The detector is designed to provide unambiguous evidence for antihydrogen production by detecting the temporally and spatially coincident [[annihilation]]s of the antiproton and positron when a neutral antihydrogen atom escapes the electromagnetic trap and strikes the trap electrodes. An antiproton typically annihilates into a few charged or neutral pions. The charged pions are detected by two layers of double-sided, position sensitive, silicon microstrips. The path of a charged particle passing through both layers can be reconstructed, and two or more intersecting tracks allow determination of the position, or vertex, of the antiproton annihilation. The uncertainty in vertex determination is approximately 4 mm and is dominated by the unmeasured curvature of the charged [[pion]]s’ trajectories in the magnetic field. The temporal coincidence window is approximately 5 microseconds. The solid angle coverage of the interaction region is about 80% of 4π. A positron annihilating with an electron yields two or three [[photons]]. The positron detector, comprising 16 rows each containing 12 scintillating, pure CsI crystals, is designed to detect the two-photon events, consisting of two 511 keV photons which are always emitted back-to-back. The energy resolution of the detector is 18% FWHM at 511 keV, and the photo-peak detection efficiency for single photons is about 20%. The maximum readout rate of the whole detector is about 40 Hz. Ancillary detectors include large scintillator paddles external to the magnet, and a thin, position sensitive, silicon diode through which the incident antiproton beam passes before entering the catching trap. To produce antihydrogen atoms, a positron well in the mixing region is filled with about {{val|7|e=7}} positrons and allowed to cool to the ambient temperature (15 K). The nested trap is then formed around the positron well. Next, approximately 104 antiprotons are launched into the mixing region by pulsing the trap from one potential configuration (dashed line, Fig. 1b) to another (solid line). The mixing time is 190 s, after which all particles are dumped and the process repeated. Events triggering the imaging silicon detector (three sides hit in the outer layer) initiate readout of both the silicon and the CsI modules. Using this method, ATHENA could produce - for the first time - several thousands of cold antihydrogen atoms in 2002. {{cite journal |last1=Amoretti |first1=M. |display-authors=etal |collaboration=ATHENA Collaboration |title=The ATHENA antihydrogen apparatus |journal=[[Nuclear Instruments and Methods in Physics Research Section A]] |date=February 2004 |volume=518 |issue=3 |pages=679–711 |doi=10.1016/j.nima.2003.09.052|bibcode=2004NIMPA.518..679A }} ===ATHENA collaboration=== The ATHENA collaboration comprised the following institutions: {{cite web |url = http://athena-positrons.web.cern.ch/ATHENA-positrons/wwwathena/collaboration.html |title = The ATHENA Collaboration |publisher = [[CERN]] |accessdate = 2010-02-01 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20120301040118/http://athena-positrons.web.cern.ch/ATHENA-positrons/wwwathena/collaboration.html |archivedate = 1 March 2012 |df = dmy-all }} {{columns-list|colwidth=30em| * [[Aarhus University]], Denmark * [[University of Brescia]], Italy * [[CERN]] * [[University of Genoa]], Italy * [[University of Pavia]], Italy * [[RIKEN]], Japan * [[Federal University of Rio de Janeiro]], Brazil * [[Swansea University]], UK * [[University of Tokyo]], Japan * [[University of Zurich]], Switzerland * [[INFN|National Institute for Nuclear Physics]], Italy }} ==ATRAP== The '''ATRAP''' collaboration at [[CERN]] developed out of [[TRAP experiment|TRAP]], a collaboration whose members pioneered cold [[antiproton]]s, cold [[positron]]s, and first made the ingredients of cold [[antihydrogen]] to interact. ATRAP members also pioneered accurate [[hydrogen]] [[spectroscopy]] and first observed hot antihydrogen atoms. ===Positron production and accumulation=== ATRAP is a collaboration between physicists around the world with the goal of creating and experimenting with antihydrogen. ATRAP accumulates positrons emitted from a radioactive [[Sodium|22Na]] source. There are two effective ways to slow down the fast positrons by inelastic processes. The ATRAP collaboration initially chose a different method to ATHENA. The positrons which were emitted by the 22Na were first slowed down with a 10 µm thick titanium foil and then passed through a 2 µm thick tungsten crystal. Within the crystal there is a possibility that a positively charged positron and a negatively charged electron form a [[Rydberg atom|Rydberg]] [[Positronium]] atom. In this process, the positrons lose much of their energy so that it is no longer necessary (as in ATHENA) to decelerate further with collisions in gas. When the loosely bound Rydberg positronium atom reaches the Penning trap at the end of the apparatus, it is [[Ionization|ionized]] and the positron is caught in the trap. Since this method of positron accumulation was not particularly efficient, ATRAP switched to a Surko-type buffer gas accumulator as is now standard in experiments requiring large numbers of positrons.{{cite web|url=http://positrons.ucsd.edu/publications.php|title=UC San Diego: Department of Physics - Surko Plasma Research Group|publisher=|accessdate=21 December 2016}} This has led to the storage of the largest ever number of positrons in an Ioffe trap.{{cite journal |last1=Fitzakerley |first1=D. W. |display-authors=etal |collaboration=ATRAP Collaboration |year=2016 |title=Electron-cooled accumulation of {{val|4|e=9}} positrons for production and storage of antihydrogen atoms |journal=[[Journal of Physics B]] |volume=49 |issue=6 |pages=064001|doi=10.1088/0953-4075/49/6/064001|bibcode=2016JPhB...49f4001F }} Unlike ATHENA, ATRAP has not yet been terminated and can be continuously improved and expanded. ATRAP now has a [[Magnetic trap (atoms)|Ioffe trap]], which can store the electrically neutral antihydrogen using a magnetic quadrupole field. This is possible because the magnetic moment of antihydrogen is non-zero. It is intended that laser spectroscopy will be performed on antihydrogen stored in the Ioffe trap. ===ATRAP collaboration=== The ATRAP collaboration comprises the following institutions: {{columns-list|colwidth=30em| *[[Harvard University]], USA *[[York University]], Canada *[[University of Mainz]], Germany *[[Forschungszentrum Jülich]], Germany }} ==ASACUSA== '''ASACUSA''' (Atomic Spectroscopy And Collisions Using Slow Antiprotons) is an experiment testing for [[CPT-symmetry]] by laser spectroscopy of [[antiprotonic helium]] and microwave spectroscopy of the [[hyperfine structure]] of [[antihydrogen]]. It also measures atomic and nuclear [[Cross section (physics)|cross sections]] of antiprotons on various targets at extremely low energies.http://asacusa.web.cern.ch/ASACUSA/ The spokesperson for the experiment is [[Ryugo S. Hayano]] from the [[University of Tokyo]]. It was originally proposed in 1997.{{cite web|url=http://asacusa.web.cern.ch/ASACUSA/home/general.html|title=ASACUSA - General|publisher=|accessdate=21 December 2016}}http://asacusa.web.cern.ch/ASACUSA/home/spsc/proposal.pdf ==ACE== The Antiproton Cell Experiment (ACE) started in 2003. It aims to assess fully the effectiveness and suitability of antiprotons for cancer therapy.{{cite web|url=http://home.web.cern.ch/about/experiments/ace|title=ACE - CERN|publisher=|accessdate=21 December 2016}} ==ALPHA== [[File:AlphaCollaboration.png|thumb|200px|right|ALPHA Logo]] The '''ALPHA''' experiment is designed to trap neutral [[antihydrogen]] in a [[magnetic trap (atoms)|magnetic trap]], and conduct experiments on them. The ultimate goal of this endeavour is to test [[CPT symmetry]] through comparison of the [[atomic spectra]] of [[hydrogen]] and antihydrogen (see [[hydrogen spectral series]]).{{cite journal |title=Cold antihydrogen: a new frontier in fundamental physics |last=Madsen |first=N. |journal=[[Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society A]] |volume=368 |date=2010 |pages=3671–82 |url=http://rsta.royalsocietypublishing.org/content/roypta/368/1924/3671.full.pdf |doi=10.1098/rsta.2010.0026 |pmid=20603376|bibcode = 2010RSPTA.368.3671M |issue=1924 }} The ALPHA collaboration consists of some former members of the [[#ATHENA|ATHENA collaboration]] (the first group to produce cold antihydrogen, in 2002), as well as a number of new members. ===ALPHA physics=== ALPHA faces several challenges. Magnetic traps – wherein neutral atoms are trapped using their [[magnetic moment]]s – are notoriously weak; only atoms with kinetic energies equivalent to less than one [[kelvin]] may be trapped. The cold antihydrogen created first in 2002 by the [[#ATHENA|ATHENA]] and the [[#ATRAP|ATRAP]] collaborations was produced by merging cold [[Plasma (physics)|plasmas]] of [[positron]]s (also called antielectrons) and [[antiproton]]s. While this method has been quite successful, it creates antiatoms with kinetic energies too large to be trapped. Furthermore, to do [[laser spectroscopy]] on these anti-atoms, it is important that they are in their [[ground state]], something which does not seem to be the case for the majority of the anti-atoms created thus far. Antiprotons are received by the Antiproton Decelerator and are 'mixed' with positrons from a specially-designed positron accumulator in a versatile [[Penning trap]]. The central region where the mixing and thus antihydrogen formation takes place is surrounded by a [[superconducting]] octupole magnet and two axially separated short solenoids "mirror-coils" to form a "minimum-[[B-field|B]]" magnetic trap. Once trapped [[antihydrogen]] can be subjected to detailed study and be compared to [[hydrogen]]. In order to detect trapped [[antihydrogen]] atoms ALPHA also comprises a silicon vertex detector. This cylindrically shaped detector consists of three layers of silicon panels (strips). Each panel acts as a position sensitive detector for charged particles passing through. By recording how the panels are excited ALPHA can reconstruct the tracks of charged particles traveling through their detector. When an antiproton annihilates (disintegrates) the process typically results in the emission of 3-4 charged [[pion]]s. These can be observed by the ALPHA detector and by reconstructing their tracks through the detector their origin, and thus the location of the annihilation, can be determined. These tracks are quite distinct from the tracks of cosmic rays which are also detected but are of high energy and pass straight through the detector. By carefully analyzing the tracks ALPHA distinguishes between cosmic rays and antiproton annihilations. To detect successful trapping the ALPHA trap magnet that created the minimum B-field was designed to allow it to be quickly and repeatedly de-energized. The currents' decay during de-energization has a characteristic time of 9 ms, orders of magnitude faster than similar systems. This fast turn-off and the ability to suppress false signal from cosmic rays should allow ALPHA to detect the release of even a single trapped antihydrogen atom during de-energization of the trap. In order to make antihydrogen cold enough to be trapped the ALPHA collaboration has implemented a novel technique, well known from atomic physics, called evaporative cooling.{{cite web |date=2010 |url=http://focus.aps.org/story/v26/st1 |title=The Coolest Antiprotons |publisher=[[American Physical Society]] |accessdate=2010-07-02| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100704021800/http://focus.aps.org/story/v26/st1| archivedate= 4 July 2010 | deadurl= no}} The motivation for this is that one of the main challenges of trapping antihydrogen is to make it cold enough. State-of-the art minimum-B traps like the one ALPHA comprises have depths in temperature units of order one Kelvin. As no readily available techniques exist to cool antihydrogen, the constituents must be cold and kept cold for the formation. Antiprotons and positrons are not easily cooled to cryogenic temperatures and the implementation of evaporative cooling is thus an important step towards antihydrogen trapping. ALPHA is presently studying the gravitational properties of antimatter.{{cite web|url=https://cosmosmagazine.com/physics/universe-shouldn-t-exist-cern-physicists-conclude|title=Universe shouldn’t exist, CERN physicists conclude|date=2017-10-23|publisher=Cosmos Magazine}} A preliminary experiment in 2013 found that the [[gravitational mass]] of [[antihydrogen atom]]s was between -65 and 110 times their [[Mass#Inertial mass|inertial mass]], leaving considerable room for refinement using larger numbers of colder antihydrogen atoms.{{cite web|url=http://alpha.web.cern.ch/news|title=ALPHA probes antimatter gravity|publisher=CERN/Alpha experiment|date=2013-04-30}}{{cite journal|url=https://www.nature.com/articles/ncomms2787|title=Description and first application of a new technique to measure the gravitational mass of antihydrogen|author=The ALPHA Collaboration & A. E. Charman|journal=Nature Communications|volume=4|doi=10.1038/ncomms2787|year=2013|bibcode=2013NatCo...4E1785A}} Article number: 1785. === ALPHA collaboration === The ALPHA collaboration comprises the following institutions: {{columns-list|colwidth=30em| *[[Aarhus University]], Denmark *[[University of British Columbia]], Canada *[[University of California, Berkeley]], USA *[[University of Calgary]], Canada *[[University of Liverpool]], UK *[[University of Manitoba]], Canada *[[Negev Nuclear Research Center]], Israel *[[Purdue University]], USA *[[RIKEN]], Japan *[[Federal University of Rio de Janeiro]], Brazil *[[Swansea University]], UK *[[University of Tokyo]], Japan *[[York University]], Canada *[[TRIUMF]], Canada }} ==AEgIS== '''AEgIS''' ('''A'''ntimatter '''E'''xperiment: '''g'''ravity, '''I'''nterferometry, '''S'''pectroscopy), is an experiment currently being set up at the Antiproton Decelerator. ===AEgIS physics=== AEgIS would attempt to determine if [[gravity]] affects [[antimatter]] in the same way it affects [[matter]] by testing its effect on an [[antihydrogen]] beam. The first phase of the experiment creates antihydrogen: antiprotons from the Antiproton Decelerator are coupled with [[positron]]s, making a pulse of horizontally-travelling antihydrogen atoms. These atoms are sent through a series of [[diffraction grating]]s, ultimately hitting a surface and thus [[annihilate|annihilating]]. The points where the antihydrogen annihilates are measured with a precise detector. Areas behind the gratings are shadowed, while those behind the slits are not. The annihilation points reproduce a periodic pattern of light and shadowed areas. Using this pattern, it can be measured how many atoms of different velocities drop during horizontal flight. Therefore, the Earth's gravitational force on antihydrogen can be determined. {{cite web |author=Aegis Collaboration |date=2014 |url=https://aegis.web.cern.ch/aegis/research.html |title=AEgIS Experiment |work=[[CERN]] |accessdate=2017-06-20 }} It was originally proposed in 2007.http://cdsweb.cern.ch/record/1037532/files/spsc-2007-017.pdf Construction of the main apparatus was completed in 2012. ===AEgIS collaboration=== The AEgIS collaboration comprises the following institutions: {{columns-list|colwidth=30em| *[[University of Bergen]], Norway *[[University of Bern]], Switzerland *[[Istituto Nazionale di Fisica Nucleare]], Italy *[[ETH Zurich]], Switzerland *[[University College London]], United Kingdom *[[Max Planck Institute for Nuclear Physics]], Germany *[[University of Oslo]], Norway *[[Czech Technical University in Prague]], Czech Republic *[[Stefan Meyer Institute]], Austria *[[Institute of Nuclear Research of The Russian Academy of Science]], Russia *[[Université de Lyon]], France *[[Université de Paris Sud]], France }} ==GBAR== '''GBAR''' ('''G'''ravitational '''B'''ehaviour of '''A'''nti hydrogen at '''R'''est), is a multinational collaboration at the Antiproton Decelerator (AD) of CERN. The GBAR project, aims to measure the free fall acceleration of ultracold neutral anti [[Antihydrogen|hydrogen atoms]] in the terrestrial [[gravitational field]]. The experiment consists preparing anti hydrogen [[ion]]s (one [[antiproton]] and two [[positron]]s) and sympathetically cooling them with Be + ions to less than 10 μK. The ultracold ions will then be [[Photoionization|photoionized]] just above threshold, and the free fall time over a known distance measured.{{cite journal |last1=Pérez |first1=P. |display-authors=etal |year=2015 |title=The GBAR antimatter gravity experiment |journal=[[Hyperfine Interactions]] |volume=233 |issue=1–3 |pages=21–27 |doi=10.1007/s10751-015-1154-8|bibcode=2015HyInt.233...21P }} === GBAR collaboration === The GBAR collaboration comprises the following institutions: {{columns-list|colwidth=30em| *[[Commissariat à l'énergie atomique]], France *[[ETH Zurich]], Swiss *[[University of Mainz]], Germany *[[Laboratoire Kastler-Brossel]], France *[[CSNSM]], France *[[RIKEN]], Japan *[[University of Tokyo]], Japan *[[Université de Strasbourg]], France *[[Uppsala University]], Sweden *[[Stockholm University]], Sweden *[[Swansea University]], UK *[[NCBJ]], Poland }} ==BASE== [[File:BASE logo.jpg|thumb|official BASE logo]] '''BASE''' ('''B'''aryon '''A'''ntibaryon '''S'''ymmetry '''E'''xperiment), is a multinational collaboration at the Antiproton Decelerator (AD) of CERN. The goal of the Japanese/German BASE collaboration {{cite news |url=http://base.web.cern.ch| title= official BASE website}} are high-precision investigations of the fundamental properties of the antiproton, namely the charge-to-mass ratio and the magnetic moment. To this end single antiprotons are stored in an advanced [[Penning trap]] system, which has a double-trap system at its core. It consists of a precision trap and an analysis trap. The precision trap is for high precision frequency measurements, the analysis trap has a strong magnetic field inhomogeneity superimposed, which is used for single particle [[Spin-flip|spin flip]] [[spectroscopy]]. By measuring the spin flip rate as a function of the frequency of an externally applied magnetic-drive, a resonance curve is obtained. Together with a measurement of the cyclotron frequency, the magnetic moment is extracted. The BASE collaboration developed techniques to observe the first spin flips of a single trapped proton{{cite journal |last1=Ulmer |first1=S. |display-authors=etal. |title=Observation of Spin Flips with a Single Trapped Proton |journal=[[Physical Review Letters]] |date=20 June 2011 |volume=106 |issue=25 |pages=253001 |doi=10.1103/PhysRevLett.106.253001|bibcode=2011PhRvL.106y3001U |arxiv = 1104.1206 }} and applied the double-trap technique to measure the magnetic moment of the proton with a fractional precision of three parts in a billion,{{cite journal |last1=Mooser |first1=A. |display-authors=etal |year=2014 |title=Direct high-precision measurement of the magnetic moment of the proton |journal=[[Nature (journal)|Nature]] |volume=509 |issue=7502 |pages=596–599 |doi=10.1038/nature13388|bibcode=2014Natur.509..596M |arxiv = 1406.4888 }} being the most precise measurement of this fundamental property of the proton. The application of the technique to measure the magnetic moment of the antiproton with similar precision will improve the precision of this value by at least a factor of 1000, and will provide one of the most stringent tests of CPT invariance to date. === BASE collaboration === The BASE collaboration comprises the following institutions: {{columns-list|colwidth=30em| *[[RIKEN]], Japan *[[University of Tokyo]], Japan *[[Max Planck Institute for Nuclear Physics]], Germany *[[University of Mainz]], Germany *[[GSI Helmholtz Centre for Heavy Ion Research|GSI]], Germany *[[University of Hanover|University of Hannover]], Germany }} ==See also== * [[Antimatter]] * [[Antihydrogen]] * [[Gravitational interaction of antimatter]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==Further reading== *{{cite web |author=G. Gache |date =12 July 2008 |title=How would antimatter interact with gravity? |url=http://news.softpedia.com/news/How-Would-Antimatter-Interact-With-Gravity-87873.shtml |publisher=[[Softpedia]] }} *{{cite web |author=G. Drobychev |collaboration=AEGIS collaboration |date=8 June 2007 |title=Proposal for the AEGIS experiment at the CERN Antiproton Decelerator (Antimatter Experiment: Gravity, Interferometry, Spectroscopy) |url=http://doc.cern.ch//archive/electronic/cern/preprints/spsc/public/spsc-2007-017.pdf |publisher=[[CERN]] |display-authors=etal}} *{{cite journal |author=G. Testera |date=2008 |title=Formation of a cold antihydrogen beam in AEGIS for gravity measurements |journal=[[AIP Conference Proceedings]] |volume=1037 |pages=5–15 |doi= 10.1063/1.2977857 |arxiv=0805.4727 |display-authors=etal|bibcode=2008AIPC.1037....5T }} ==External links== *[http://psdoc.web.cern.ch/PSdoc/acc/ad/index.html AD website] **[http://athena.web.cern.ch/athena/ ATHENA website] **[http://hussle.harvard.edu/~atrap/ ATRAP website] **[http://asacusa.web.cern.ch/ASACUSA/ ASACUSA website] **[http://alpha.web.cern.ch ALPHA website] **[http://aegis.web.cern.ch/aegis/ AEgIS website] *{{cite web |title=What is the AD? |url=http://livefromcern.web.cern.ch/livefromcern/antimatter/factory/AM-factory01.html |publisher=[[CERN]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060215142404/http://livefromcern.web.cern.ch/livefromcern/antimatter/factory/AM-factory01.html |archivedate=15 February 2006 }} *{{cite web |title=ATHENA figures and pictures |url=http://athena-positrons.web.cern.ch/ATHENA-positrons/wwwathena/figpic.html |publisher=[[CERN]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070622215609/http://athena-positrons.web.cern.ch/ATHENA-positrons/wwwathena/figpic.html |archivedate=22 June 2007 }} {{CERN}} {{coord|46|14|02|N|6|02|47|E|region:CH-GE_type:landmark_source:kolossus-dewiki|display=title}} {{Use dmy dates|date=January 2011}} [[Category:Antimatter]] [[Category:CERN accelerators]] [[Category:Research projects]] [[Category:Particle experiments]] [[Category:Particle physics facilities]] [[es:Proyecto Athena]] [[fr:ALPHA (expérience)]] [[fr:AEGIS (Physique des particules)]] [[pt:ATRAP]] [[simple:ALPHA Collaboration]]

'''Antony Froggatt''' is an [[energy policy]] consultant and a senior research fellow at [[Chatham House]]. He is co-author of ''[[The World Nuclear Industry Status Report]]s''.
==Biography== Antony Froggatt is a senior research fellow in the Energy, Environment and Development Programme at Chatham House and has been a freelance energy policy consultant since 1997, based in London. Previously, he was the [[Greenpeace International]] Nuclear Policy Campaigner.<ref>[http://www.chathamhouse.org.uk/about/directory/view/-/id/129/ Chatham House Experts: Antony Froggatt] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101229134441/http://www.chathamhouse.org.uk/about/directory/view/-/id/129/ |date=December 29, 2010 }}</ref>
==Recent work== With [[Mycle Schneider]], Froggatt is co-author of ''[[The World Nuclear Industry Status Report]]s'', which suggest that [[nuclear power]] will continue to decline.<ref>Mycle Schneider, [[Stephen Thomas (professor)|Steve Thomas]], Antony Froggatt, and Doug Koplow (August 2009). [http://www.bmu.de/english/nuclear_safety/downloads/doc/44832.php The World Nuclear Industry Status Report 2009] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110424000745/http://www.bmu.de/english/nuclear_safety/downloads/doc/44832.php |date=2011-04-24 }} Commissioned by German Federal Ministry of Environment, Nature Conservation and Reactor Safety.</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.neimagazine.com/story.asp?storyCode=2053966|title=Nuclear decline set to continue, says report|date=27 August 2009|work=Nuclear Engineering International|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120319191247/http://www.neimagazine.com/story.asp?storyCode=2053966|archivedate=19 March 2012}}</ref> Froggatt and Schneider wrote the ''Systems for Change'' report for the [[Heinrich Böll Foundation]] in 2010.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.boell.eu/downloads/Froggatt_Schneider_Systems_for_Change.pdf|title=Systems for Change: Nuclear Power vs. Energy Efficiency+Renewables?|author=Antony Froggatt with Mycle Schneider|date=2010|publisher=Heinrich Böll Foundation}}</ref> Froggatt has commented extensively on the [[2011 Japanese nuclear accidents]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chinadialogue.net/article/show/single/en/4168-What-next-for-Chinese-nuclear|title=What next for Chinese nuclear?|author=Antony Froggatt|date=March 17, 2011 |work=Chinadialogue }</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-12729357|title=Japan nuclear risks could hurt industry growth in Asia|author=Saira Syed|date=14 March 2011|work=BBC}}</ref><ref name=viewpoint>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-pacific-12960655|title=Viewpoint: Fukushima makes case for renewable energy|author=Antony Froggatt|date=4 April 2011|work=BBC News}}</ref> He says "that the cascade of problems at Fukushima, from one reactor to another, and from reactors to fuel storage pools, will affect the design, layout and ultimately the cost of future nuclear plants".<ref name=viewpoint/>
==See also== {{Portal|Biography}} *[[Energy Fair]] *[[Anti-nuclear movement]] *[[Non-nuclear future]] *[[Stephen Thomas (professor)|Stephen Thomas]] *[[Nuclear renaissance]] *[[Amory Lovins]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==Further reading== *{{cite web |url=http://bos.sagepub.com/content/68/5/8.abstract?etoc |title=2011–2012 World Nuclear Industry Status Report |author=Mycle Schneider |author2=Antony Froggatt |last-author-amp=yes |date=September–October 2012 |volume=68|number=5 |work=Bulletin of the Atomic Scientists |pages=8–22 }} *{{cite web |url=http://bos.sagepub.com/content/67/4/60.abstract |title=2010–2011 World Nuclear Industry Status Report |author=Mycle Schneider |author2=Antony Froggatt |author3=Steve Thomas |last-author-amp=yes |date=July 2011 |volume=67 |issue=4 |work=Bulletin of the Atomic Scientists }} *Mycle Schneider, Antony Froggatt, and Steve Thomas (2011). ''[http://www.worldwatch.org/system/files/WorldNuclearIndustryStatusReport2011_%20FINAL.pdf World Nuclear Industry Status Report 2010-2011: Nuclear Power in a Post-Fukushima World]'', [[Worldwatch Institute]]. *{{cite web|url=http://www.thebulletin.org/web-edition/features/fukushima-crisis-can-japan-be-the-forefront-of-authentic-paradigm-shift |title=Fukushima crisis: Can Japan be at the forefront of an authentic paradigm shift? |author=Mycle Schneider |date=9 September 2011 |work=[[Bulletin of the Atomic Scientists]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130106021131/http://www.thebulletin.org/web-edition/features/fukushima-crisis-can-japan-be-the-forefront-of-authentic-paradigm-shift |archivedate=6 January 2013 }}
==External links== *[http://wn.com/antony_froggatt_on_energy_security_supply_threat Antony Froggatt on energy security supply threat] *[http://www.ukrweekly.com/old/archive/1996/169611.shtml Interview: Antony Froggatt, Greenpeace representative in Ukraine] *[http://www.worldnuclearreport.org/ The World Nuclear Industry Status Reports website]
