[[Image:Hurricane Isabel 18 sept 2003 1555Z.jpg|right|200px|thumb|[[Hurricane Isabel]], one of the most significant storms to affect the region, on September 18, 2003]] Since 1950, 121 known [[tropical cyclone|hurricanes]], tropical storms and tropical depressions have affected the [[U.S. state]] of [[Maryland]]. Many of these storms also affect the country's capital, [[Washington, D.C.]], since the city is located on territory ceded by Maryland. Hurricanes are the most intense classification of these storms, while tropical storms and tropical depressions are generally weaker. The [[Delmarva Peninsula]] is often affected by cyclones that brush the [[U.S. East Coast|East Coast]].<ref>{{cite web|author=[[Tropical Prediction Center]]|title=Best Track Analysis|publisher=[[Unisys Corporation]]|accessdate=2008-05-08|url=http://weather.unisys.com/hurricane/atlantic/index.html|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20051028061629/http://weather.unisys.com/hurricane/atlantic/index.html|archive-date=2005-10-28|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> Central and [[Western Maryland]], as well as Washington, D.C., commonly receive rainfall from the remnants of storms that make landfall elsewhere and track northward.<ref name="Mid Atl"/> On rare occasions, the area experiences the effects of [[Pacific hurricane|Pacific storms]]; one such example of this is [[Hurricane Tico (1983)|Hurricane Tico]], which made landfall on [[Mexico]] and moved inland.
[[Hurricane Agnes]] of the [[1972 Atlantic hurricane season|1972 season]] was the deadliest storm, killing 19 people as a result of heavy flooding. The most damaging storm was [[Hurricane Irene (2011)|Hurricane Irene]], which resulted in $151 million in damage. [[Hurricane Hazel]] caused sustained hurricane-force winds (winds of 75 mph (121 km/h) or greater) in the state, the only storm during the time period to do so.<ref name="chron" /> No storms made landfall in Maryland at hurricane intensity. Since 1950, twelve tropical cyclones have collectively killed 61 people.
==1950–1959== [[Image:Dog 1950 track.png|right|thumb|Hurricane Dog track]] *September 9, 1950 – Outer moisture from [[Hurricane Dog (1950)|Hurricane Dog]] drops heavy rainfall in the Mid-Atlantic. In [[Bel Air, Harford County, Maryland|Bel Air]], a car drove into the swollen [[Gunpowder River]]; three people in the car drowned and a fourth was injured.<ref name="ls912">{{cite news|author=''Lowell Sun''|date=1950-09-12|title=Hurricane Misses Nantucket}}</ref> *September 1, 1952 – [[Hurricane Able (1952)|Tropical Storm Able]] crosses the state, although damage, if any, is unknown.<ref name="hurdat">{{cite web|author=[[Hurricane Research Division]]|year=2008|title=Best Track of Atlantic tropical cyclones (1851–2007)|publisher=National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration|accessdate=2008-08-24|url=http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/hrd/hurdat/easyhurdat_5107.html}}</ref> *October 15, 1954 – [[Hurricane Hazel]] crosses the state, producing hurricane-force winds.<ref name="chron">{{cite web|author=Hurricane Research Division |year=2008 |title=Chronological List of All Hurricanes which Affected the Continental United States: 1851-2007 |publisher=National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration |accessdate=2008-03-21 |url=http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/hrd/hurdat/ushurrlist18512007.txt |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080921102626/http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/hrd/hurdat/ushurrlist18512007.txt |archivedate=2008-09-21 |df= }}</ref> In addition to wind damage, flooding was severe along the [[Chesapeake Bay]], while [[flash flooding]] was reported inland.<ref name="Maryland hurricanes"/> Overall, six deaths and about $11 million in damage were reported.<ref name="flooding"/> *August 12, 1955 – [[Hurricane Connie|Tropical Storm Connie]] makes landfall in southern Maryland, dropping heavy rainfall peaking at {{convert|12.32|in|mm|abbr=on}} in [[Preston, Maryland|Preston]].<ref name="Mid Atl"/> The rainfall leads to flooding which causes $2.5 million in damage. When the [[schooner]] ''Levin J. Marvel'' capsizes in high seas, 14 people drown.<ref name="Maryland floods">{{cite web|author=R.W. James, Jr|title=Maryland and the District of Columbia: Floods and Droughts|year=2008|publisher=USGS|accessdate=2008-08-24 |url=http://md.water.usgs.gov/publications/wsp-2375/md-dc/md-dc-html.html}}</ref> *August 18, 1955 – As [[Hurricane Diane|Tropical Storm Diane]] begins its turn to the east-northeast over Virginia, associated heavy rains, combined with saturated grounds from Connie just days before, cause flooding in central parts of the state, especially along the [[Potomac River]].<ref name="Maryland hurricanes">{{cite web|title=Hurricanes and Maryland|year=2008|publisher=Midatlantichurricanes.com|accessdate=2008-08-24|url=http://www.midatlantichurricanes.com/Maryland.html|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080915235130/http://www.midatlantichurricanes.com/Maryland.html|archive-date=2008-09-15|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> *September 19, 1955 – [[Hurricane Ione]] makes landfall in [[North Carolina]]; its outer moisture produces light rainfall across the state.<ref>{{cite web|author=David Roth|year=2006|title=Hurricane Ione - September 18–20, 1955|publisher=Hydrometeorological Prediction Center|accessdate=2008-08-24|url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/tropical/rain/ione1955.html}}</ref> *September 28, 1956 – [[Hurricane Flossy (1956)|Hurricane Flossy]] passes southeast of the state, producing up to {{convert|3.30|in|mm|abbr=on}} of rain. In nearby [[Washington, D.C.]], a peak wind gust of {{convert|45|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} is reported.<ref name="Virginia hurricanes"/> *September 28, 1958 – [[Hurricane Helene (1958)|Hurricane Helene]] remains well off of the [[Carolinas|Carolina]] coast, though light rain falls across the [[Mid-Atlantic States|Mid-Atlantic]] states.<ref>{{cite web|author=David Roth|title=Hurricane Helene - September 25–29, 1958|year=|publisher=Hydrometeorological Prediction Center|accessdate=2008-08-24|url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/tropical/rain/helene1958.html}}</ref> *September 30, 1959 – The remnants of [[Hurricane Gracie]] drop moderate rainfall over western Maryland.<ref name="Mid Atl"/>
==1960–1969== *July 30, 1960 – [[Tropical Storm Brenda (1960)|Tropical Storm Brenda]] crosses southeastern Maryland. The storm's rainfall causes flooding in [[St. Mary's County, Maryland|St. Mary's County]].<ref name="flooding"/> *September 12, 1960 – [[Hurricane Donna]] passes just offshore, producing wind gusts of over {{convert|100|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} in Ocean City.<ref>{{cite web|author=Michael A. Grammatico|title=Major Hurricanes - Virginia to Massachusetts|year=|publisher=Geocities.com|accessdate=2008-08-24|url=http://www.geocities.com/hurricanene/Majorne.htm|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080415193340/http://www.geocities.com/hurricanene/Majorne.htm|archivedate=2008-04-15}}</ref> Flooding along the eastern shore causes two deaths.<ref name="flooding"/> *September 21, 1961 – [[Hurricane Esther (1961)|Hurricane Esther]] moves northward, parallel to the coast. Wind gusts to 45 mph (70 km/h) are observed at Ocean City, and storm surge flooding causes damage to the city's [[sea wall]] and [[boardwalk]].<ref name="Prelimreport">{{cite web | url = http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/archive/storm_wallets/atlantic/atl1961/esther/prenhc/prelim01.gif | title = Hurricane Esther Tropical Cyclone Report (page 1) | accessdate = 2006-06-09 | year = 1961 | publisher = NOAA}}</ref> [[Image:Camille_1969_rainfall.png|right|thumb|Camille rainfall map]] *September 1, 1964 – In [[Westernport, Maryland|Westernport]], {{convert|5.80|in|mm|abbr=on}} of rain falls as [[Hurricane Cleo|Tropical Storm Cleo]] tracks just south of the state.<ref name="Mid Atl"/> *October 4, 1964 – The remnants of [[Hurricane Hilda]] cause light to moderate precipitation.<ref name="Mid Atl"/> *October 17, 1964 – The remnants of [[Hurricane Isbell (1964)|Hurricane Isbell]] drop light rainfall.<ref name="Mid Atl"/> *September 13, 1965 – The remnants of [[Hurricane Betsy]] produce light rainfall across western part of the state.<ref>{{cite web|author=David Roth|title=Hurricane Betsy - September 6–13, 1965|year=|publisher=Hydometeorological Prediction Center|accessdate=2008-08-24|url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/tropical/rain/betsy1965.html}}</ref> *September 16, 1967 – [[Hurricane Doria (1967)|Tropical Storm Doria]] makes landfall in Virginia; associated high seas damage the [[boardwalk]] at Ocean City.<ref>{{cite web|title=Hurricane Doria|year=1967|publisher=U.S. Department of Commence|accessdate=2008-08-24|url=http://docs.lib.noaa.gov/rescue/hurricanes/Qc9452d67h81967.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref> *June 13, 1968 – [[Hurricane Abby (1968)|Tropical Depression Abby]] produces {{convert|3.83|in|mm|abbr=on}} of rainfall at [[Centreville, Maryland|Centreville]].<ref name="Mid Atl"/> *June 26, 1968 – The remnants of [[Tropical Storm Candy]] drop moderate rainfall.<ref name="Mid Atl"/> *September 11, 1968 – [[1968 Atlantic hurricane season#Tropical Depression Fourteen|Tropical Depression Fourteen]] produces {{convert|4.68|in|mm|abbr=on}} of rain near [[Parkton, Maryland|Parkton]].<ref name="Mid Atl"/> *October 20, 1968 – As [[Hurricane Gladys (1968)|Hurricane Gladys]] parallels the east coast, tides of up to {{convert|4|ft|m|abbr=on}} are felt along the coast. As a result, street flooding is reported in Ocean City.<ref>{{cite web|title=Hurricane Gladys, September 13–25, 1961|year=1968|publisher=U.S. Weather Bureau|accessdate=2008-08-24|url=http://docs.lib.noaa.gov/rescue/hurricanes/Qc9452g63h81964.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref> *August 20, 1969 – The remnants of [[Hurricane Camille]] cause extensive flooding in [[Virginia]],<ref name="Virginia hurricanes">{{cite web|author=David Roth|title=Virginia Hurricane History: Late Twentieth Century|year=|publisher=Hydrometeorological Prediction Center|accessdate=2008-08-24|url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/research/roth/valate20hur.htm}}</ref> though they drop only moderate rainfall peaking at {{convert|6.55|in|mm|abbr=on}} in Maryland.<ref name="Mid Atl"/> *September 9, 1969 – [[Hurricane Gerda (1969)|Hurricane Gerda]] intensifies offshore, prompting a hurricane watch for eastern Maryland.<ref>{{cite news|author=''The Frederick Post''|year=1969|title=Hurricane Watch in the Frederick Area}}</ref> Because the storm remained offshore, only light precipitation falls.<ref name="Mid Atl"/>
==1970–1979== [[Image:Agnes2.jpg|right|thumb|Remnants of Agnes over northeastern United States]] *August 28, 1971 – [[Tropical Storm Doria (1971)|Tropical Storm Doria]] parallels the east coast, resulting in tides 2.7 feet (0.8 m) above normal in [[Fort McHenry, Maryland|Fort McHenry]].<ref>{{cite web|author1=R.H. Simpson |author2=John R. Hope |lastauthoramp=yes|year=1972|title=Atlantic Hurricane Season of 1971|publisher=National Hurricane Center|accessdate=2008-08-23|url=http://docs.lib.noaa.gov/rescue/mwr/100/mwr-100-04-0256.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref> *September 13, 1971 – [[1971 Atlantic hurricane season#Tropical Storm Heidi|Tropical Storm Heidi]] passes offshore, dropping {{convert|2.86|in|mm|abbr=on}} of rain in parts of the state.<ref name="Mid Atl"/> *Early October, 1971 – The remnants of [[Hurricane Ginger (1971)|Hurricane Ginger]] make landfall in [[North Carolina]], turn north-northeast, and brush southern Maryland with light rainfall.<ref>{{cite web|author=David Roth|title=Hurricane Ginger - September 29-October 4, 1971|year=|publisher=Hydrometeorological Prediction Center|accessdate=2008-08-23|url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/tropical/rain/ginger1971.html}}</ref> *June 2, 1972 – Heavy rainfall from [[Hurricane Agnes|Tropical Storm Agnes]], combined with a separate low to the west,<ref name="Mid Atl"/> contribute to the state's worst flooding in 36 years. Severe damage and at least 19 deaths are reported throughout the region.<ref name="flooding"/><ref>{{cite book|author1=J. F. Bailey |author2=J. L. Patterson |author3=J. L. H. Paulhus |last-author-amp=yes |work=Geological Survey Professional Paper 924|title=Hurricane Agnes Rainfall and Floods, June–July 1972|publisher=United States Government Printing Office|location=Washington D.C.|year=1975}}</ref> Throughout the state, 1,930 were damaged, of which 103 were destroyed. 17 farm buildings were destroyed and 44 damaged, and 82 small businesses were destroyed. Total damage is estimated at $80 million.<ref name="Maryland floods"/> *September 3, 1972 – [[Tropical Storm Carrie (1972)|Tropical Storm Carrie]] remains well offshore, though its outer bands drop light precipitation across the southern Delmarva Peninsula.<ref name="Mid Atl"/> *September 23 – September 26, 1975 – [[Hurricane Eloise]] becomes an [[extratropical cyclone|extratropical frontal low]] over [[Virginia]]. The storm's moisture drops {{convert|14.23|in|mm|abbr=on}} of rain in [[Westminster, Maryland|Westminster]],<ref name="Mid Atl"/> causing severe [[flooding]], particularly in the Monocacy and [[Patapsco River]] basins.<ref name="flooding">{{cite web |title = An Assessment Of Maryland’s Vulnerability To Flood Damage |year = |publisher = Eastern Shore Regional GIS Cooperative |accessdate = 2008-08-23 |url = http://www.esrgc.org/pdf/hazus/An%20Assessment%20of%20Maryland%27s%20Vulnerability%20to%20Flooding.pdf |format = PDF |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20090206150438/http://www.esrgc.org/pdf/hazus/An%20Assessment%20of%20Maryland%27s%20Vulnerability%20to%20Flooding.pdf |archive-date = 2009-02-06 |dead-url = yes |df = }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Appendix 1 |year= |publisher=Maryland Department of the Environment |accessdate=2008-08-23 |url=http://www.mde.state.md.us/assets/document/sedimentStormwater/MSSPermit/co_permit_appendix.pdf |format=PDF |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110526143055/http://www.mde.state.md.us/assets/document/sedimentStormwater/MSSPermit/co_permit_appendix.pdf |archivedate=2011-05-26 |df= }}</ref> *October 27, 1975 – [[Tropical Storm Hallie (1975)|Tropical Storm Hallie]] becomes extratropical to the east of the state; light rain falls over the southern [[Delmarva Peninsula]].<ref name="Mid Atl"/> *August 9, 1976 – [[Hurricane Belle]] parallels the east coast, prompting [[tropical cyclone warnings and watches|hurricane warnings]] for the coastline. The center of the storm passes to the east of the state, producing wind gusts of around {{convert|70|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} at [[Ocean City, Maryland|Ocean City]].<ref name="1976mwr">{{cite web|author=Lawrence|year=1976|title=1976 Monthly Weather Review|publisher=National Hurricane Center|accessdate=2006-07-27|url=http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/general/lib/lib1/nhclib/mwreviews/1976.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref> *Mid-September 1976 – [[1976 Atlantic hurricane season#Subtropical Storm Three|Subtropical Storm Three]] becomes [[Extratropical cyclone|extratropical]] to the south of the state. The resulting [[Low pressure area|low]] moves northward, dropping moderate rainfall.<ref name="Mid Atl"/> *July 29 – July 31, 1979 – The remnants of [[Tropical Storm Claudette (1979)|Tropical Storm Claudette]] drop light, spotty rainfall in southern areas.<ref>{{cite web|author=David Roth|title=Tropical Storm Claudette - July 16–31, 1979 |year=|publisher=Hydrometeorological Prediction Center|accessdate=2008-08-22|url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/tropical/rain/claudette1979.html}}</ref> *September 5, 1979 – [[Hurricane David|Tropical Storm David]] crosses the western part of the state, dropping up to {{convert|9.40|in|mm|abbr=on}} of rainfall.<ref name="Mid Atl"/> Associated bands spawn seven [[tornado]]es throughout the state.<ref>{{cite web|author=Barbara Watson |title=Virginia's Weather History |year=2008 |publisher=Virginia Department of Emergency Management |accessdate=2008-08-22 |url=http://www.vaemergency.com/newsroom/history/tornado.cfm |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050904212240/http://www.vaemergency.com/newsroom/history/tornado.cfm |archivedate=2005-09-04 |df= }}</ref> One of the tornadoes strikes near [[Crofton, Maryland|Crofton]], causing tree and structure damage, as well as one injury.<ref>{{cite web|author=Barbara Watson|title=Maryland Listing of Tornadoes by County|year=2001|publisher=Baltimore/Washington National Weather Service|accessdate=2008-08-22|url=http://www.erh.noaa.gov/lwx/Historic_Events/MDcnty-tornado-events.htm}}</ref>
==1980–1989== * June 7, 1981 – A [[tropical depression]] moves off the Mid-Atlantic coast, brushing the southern tip of Maryland with light rainfall.<ref>{{cite web|author=David Roth|title=Rainfall Summary for Tropical Depression Two|year=2008|publisher=Hydrometeorological Prediction Center|accessdate=2008-05-19|url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/tropical/rain/td2of1981.html}}</ref> * July 1, 1981 – [[Tropical Storm Bret (1981)|Tropical Storm Bret]] makes landfall on Maryland, although there is no reported damage.<ref name="hurdat"/> * August 19, 1981 – [[Hurricane Dennis (1981)|Tropical Storm Dennis]] brushes the extreme southern section of the Delmarva Peninsula, with light rainfall.<ref>{{cite web|author=David Roth|title=Rainfall Summary for Tropical Storm Dennis|year=1981|publisher=Hydrometeorological Prediction Center|accessdate=2008-05-06|url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/tropical/rain//dennis1981.html}}</ref> * September 30, 1983 – [[Tropical Storm Dean (1983)|Tropical Storm Dean]] makes landfall on [[Virginia]] and produces up to {{convert|1.32|in|mm|abbr=on}} of rainfall in the state.<ref name="Mid Atl"/> * October 25, 1983 – The remnants of [[Hurricane Tico (1983)|Hurricane Tico]], a [[Pacific hurricane|Pacific storm]], drop light rainfall across Maryland and surrounding locations.<ref>{{cite web|author=David Roth|title=Rainfall Summary for Hurricane Tico|year=1983|publisher=Hydrometeorolgical Prediction Center|accessdate=2008-05-06|url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/tropical/rain//tico1983.html}}</ref> [[Image:Hurricane Gloria1985.jpg|200px|thumb|[[Hurricane Gloria]] moving away from the Maryland coast on September 27]] * July 25, 1985 – The remnants of [[Hurricane Bob (1985)|Hurricane Bob]] cause moderate rainfall in southern Maryland, and light wind gusts.<ref name="Mid Atl"/> Rough seas from the system capsize a few boats along the [[Potomac River]], and the rainfall collapses a house under construction in [[Great Falls, Maryland]].<ref name="virhis">{{cite web|author1=David Roth |author2=Hugh Cobb |lastauthoramp=yes|year=2001|title=Late 20th Century Virginia Hurricane History|publisher=National Weather Service|accessdate=2006-10-30|url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/research/roth/valate20hur.htm}}</ref> * August 18, 1985 – Remnant moisture from [[Hurricane Danny (1985)|Hurricane Danny]] drops up to {{convert|7|in|mm|abbr=on}} of rain on the Delmarva Peninsula, although damage, if any is unknown.<ref>{{cite web|author=David Roth|title=Rainfall Summary for Hurricane Danny|year=1985|publisher=Hydrometeorological Prediction Center|accessdate=2008-05-06|url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/tropical/rain//danny1985.html}}</ref> * September 24, 1985 – [[1985 Atlantic hurricane season#Tropical Storm Henri|Tropical Storm Henri]] parallels the coastline, dropping light rainfall.<ref name="Mid Atl"/> * September 27, 1985 – [[Hurricane Gloria]] passes east of Maryland and drops over {{convert|7|in|mm|abbr=on}} of rain. Wind gusts to {{convert|40|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} blast the coastline, causing beach erosion.<ref name="1985mwr">{{cite web|author=Case|year=1985|title=1985 Monthly Weather Review|publisher=National Hurricane Center|accessdate=2006-07-27|url=http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/general/lib/lib1/nhclib/mwreviews/1985.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref> * August 18, 1986 – [[Hurricane Charley (1986)|Hurricane Charley]] tracks just miles offshore, spawning wind gusts up to {{convert|35|mph|km/h|abbr=on}}.<ref name="1986mwr">{{cite web|author=Lawrence|year=1986|title=1986 Monthly Weather Review|publisher=National Hurricane Center|accessdate=2006-07-27|url=http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/general/lib/lib1/nhclib/mwreviews/1986.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref> The storm also drops up to {{convert|4.50|in|mm|abbr=on}} of rain in Maryland.<ref name="Mid Atl"/> * September, 1987 – [[1987 Atlantic hurricane season#Tropical Depression Nine|Tropical Depression Nine]] produces up to {{convert|5|in|mm|abbr=on}} of rainfall throughout the area.<ref>{{cite web|author=David Roth|title=Rainfall Summary for Tropical Depression Nine|year=1987|publisher=Hydrometeorological Prediction Center|accessdate=2008-05-06|url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/tropical/rain//td9of1987.html}}</ref> * August 28, 1988 – The state receives light rainfall caused by [[Tropical Storm Chris (1988)|Tropical Storm Chris]].<ref name="Mid Atl"/> * Mid-October, 1989 – The remnants of [[Hurricane Jerry (1989)|Hurricane Jerry]] track eastward off the [[Mid-Atlantic States|Mid-Atlantic]] coast, dropping light amounts of rainfall in northern locales.<ref name="Mid Atl"/>
==1990–1994== * Mid-October, 1990 – The remnants of [[Tropical Storm Marco (1990)|Tropical Storm Marco]] produce moderate rainfall in western locations.<ref name="mwr">{{cite web|author1=Max Mayfield|author2=Miles B. Lawrence|lastauthoramp=yes|year=1992|title=Atlantic Hurricane Season of 1990|publisher=American Meteorological Society|accessdate=2007-11-09|url=http://ams.allenpress.com/archive/1520-0493/119/8/pdf/i1520-0493-119-8-2014.pdf|format=PDF|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=http://archive.wikiwix.com/cache/20071109152035/http://ams.allenpress.com/archive/1520-0493/119/8/pdf/i1520-0493-119-8-2014.pdf|archivedate=2007-11-09|df=}}</ref> * August 19, 1991 – [[Hurricane Bob]] passes {{convert|90|mi|km|abbr=on}} offshore, producing waves of up to {{convert|12|ft|m|abbr=on}} high.<ref>{{cite news|author1=Mary Jordan |author2=Dan Beyers |title=With a Wave, Bob Passes By; Hurricane Skirts Thankful Coast|year=1991|publisher=The Washington Post}}</ref> * Late August, 1992 – Remnant moisture from [[Hurricane Andrew]] produces up to {{convert|2.70|in|mm|abbr=on}} of rain in western areas of the state.<ref name="Mid Atl"/> [[Image:Danielle radar.JPG|200px|right|thumb|Radar image of [[Tropical Storm Danielle (1992)|Tropical Storm Danielle]] making landfall]] * September 25, 1992 – [[Tropical Storm Danielle (1992)|Tropical Storm Danielle]] makes landfall on the Delmarva Peninsula, producing winds of 53 mph (85 km/h) in Ocean City. Storm tide ranges from an estimated storm tide of 2–3 feet (0.6–0.9 m).<ref name="bwipr">{{cite web|author=Davis|year=1992|title=Danielle Preliminary Report|publisher=Baltimore National Weather Service|accessdate=2006-08-02|url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/archive/storm_wallets/atlantic/atl1992/danielle/preloc/pshbwi.gif}}</ref> The storm produces moderate rainfall of over 3 inches (76 mm) across the [[Eastern Shore of Maryland]].<ref name="rain">{{cite web|author=Hydrometeorological Prediction Center|year=2005|title=Tropical Storm Danielle Rainfall Summary|accessdate=2006-08-05|url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/tropical/rain/danielle1992.html}}</ref> * September 1, 1993 – Uncertainty in the track of [[Hurricane Emily (1993)|Hurricane Emily]] track prompts voluntary evacuations of Ocean City, although the storm quickly turns away from the state.<ref>{{cite news|author=Bill McAllister|title=Hurricane Climbs N.C. Coast to Virginia|year=1993|publisher=The Washington Post|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/national/longterm/hurricane/archives/emily93.htm|accessdate=2008-05-05}}</ref> * July 21, 1994 – [[List of storms in the 1994 Atlantic hurricane season#Tropical Depression Two|Tropical Depression Two]] passes just west of the western border with light precipitation.<ref>{{cite web|author=David Roth|title=Rainfall Summary for Tropical Depression Two|year=1994|publisher=Hydrometeorological Prediction Center|accessdate=2008-05-05|url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/tropical/rain//td2of1994.html}}</ref> * August 18, 1994 – [[Tropical Storm Beryl (1994)|Tropical Storm Beryl]]'s remnants track over western Maryland, producing light rainfall.<ref>{{cite web|author=David Roth|title=Rainfall Summary for Tropical Storm Beryl|year=1994|publisher=Hydrometeorological Prediction Center|accessdate=2008-05-05|url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/tropical/rain//beryl1994.html}}</ref> * November 20, 1994 – [[Hurricane Gordon (1994)|Hurricane Gordon]] dissipates over [[South Carolina]], dropping light to moderate rainfall over the southern Delmarva Peninsula.<ref>{{cite web|author=David Roth|title=Rainfall Summary for Hurricane Gordon|year=1994|publisher=Hydrometeorological Prediction Center|accessdate=2008-05-05|url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/tropical/rain//gordon1994.html}}</ref>
==1995–1999== * June 6, 1995 – The remnants of [[Hurricane Allison (1995)|Hurricane Allison]] produce light showers in some locations, amounting to less than an inch.<ref name="Mid Atl"/> * August 6, 1995 – Remnant moisture from [[Hurricane Erin (1995)|Hurricane Erin]] produces {{convert|4.53|in|mm|abbr=on}} of rainfall in [[Chestertown, Maryland|Chestertown]].<ref name="Mid Atl"/> * October 3, 1995 – The remnants of [[Hurricane Opal]] track well west of Maryland, producing light rainfall across the entire state.<ref name="Mid Atl"/> Moderate winds downed trees and tree limbs onto [[Maryland Route 495]].<ref>{{cite web|author=National Climatic Data Center|title=Hurricane Opal Event Report for Maryland|year=1995|publisher=|accessdate=2008-05-04|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~208433|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110520010616/http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~208433|archivedate=2011-05-20|df=}}</ref> The system spawns numerous tornadoes, the most notable of which contains winds of {{Convert|150|mph|km/h|abbr=on}}; this particular tornado results in three injuries and damages over 100 homes.<ref>{{cite web|author=National Climatic Data Center (2)|title=Hurricane Opal Event Report for Maryland|year=1995|publisher=|accessdate=2008-05-04|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~208634|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110520010633/http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~208634|archivedate=2011-05-20|df=}}</ref> [[Image:Hurricane Fran.png|right|200px|thumb|[[Hurricane Fran]] affecting Maryland while making landfall]] * July 13, 1996 – [[Hurricane Bertha (1996)|Tropical Storm Bertha]] passes over the state producing wind gusts peaking at {{Convert|63|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} at [[Ocean City, Maryland|Ocean City]]. Several trees and power lines are downed resulting in scattered power outages and property damage. In [[Dorchester County, Maryland|Dorchester]], one tornado is confirmed. Also, rainfall of up to {{convert|5|in|mm|abbr=on}} causes some street flooding.<ref>{{cite web|author=National Climatic Data Center|title=Hurricane Bertha Event Report for Maryland|year=1996|publisher=|accessdate=2008-05-04|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~260237|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110520010129/http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~260237|archivedate=2011-05-20|df=}}</ref> * September 6, 1996 – [[Hurricane Fran|Tropical Storm Fran]] tracks west of the state, spawning wind gusts of up to {{convert|55|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} which, combined with saturated soil, downs numerous trees.<ref>{{cite web|author=National Climatic Data Center|title=Hurricane Fran Event Report for Maryland|year=1996|publisher=|accessdate=2008-05-04|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~260284|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110520010140/http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~260284|archivedate=2011-05-20|df=}}</ref> Along the [[Chesapeake Bay]], a storm surge of up to {{convert|6|ft|m|abbr=on}} inundates coastal communities.<ref>{{cite web|author=National Climatic Data Center|title=Hurricane Fran Event Report for Maryland (2)|year=1996|publisher=|accessdate=2008-05-04|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~260283|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110520010149/http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~260283|archivedate=2011-05-20|df=}}</ref> This causes tidal flooding which results in one injury and forces several people to evacuate.<ref>{{cite web|author=National Climatic Data Center|title=Hurricane Fran Event Report for Maryland (3)|year=1996|publisher=|accessdate=2008-05-04|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~260300|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110520010154/http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~260300|archivedate=2011-05-20|df=}}</ref> The heavy rainfall severely floods the [[Potomac River]], damaging over 500 homes and destroying nearly {{convert|450|acre|km2}} of corn and soy crops.<ref>{{cite web|author=National Climatic Data Center|title=Hurricane Fran Event Report for Maryland (4)|year=1996|publisher=|accessdate=2008-05-04|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~260297|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110520010204/http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~260297|archivedate=2011-05-20|df=}}</ref> As a result of Fran, one death is reported,<ref>{{cite news|author=York Daily Record|title=Floods Ravage Maryland Homes Some Towns Had Flooding More Severe Than January Storms.|year=1996|publisher=}}</ref> and $50 million (1996 USD, $68 million 2008 USD) in damage is blamed on the storm.<ref>{{cite web|author=Max Mayfield |title=Tropical Cyclone Report: Hurricane Fran |year=1996 |publisher=National Hurricane Center |accessdate=2008-05-04 |url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/1996fran.html |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130703015034/http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/1996fran.html |archivedate=2013-07-03 |df= }}</ref> * October 8, 1996 – Moisture from [[Tropical Storm Josephine (1996)|Tropical Storm Josephine]] moves northward along the East Coast. Up to {{convert|3.5|in|mm|abbr=on}} of rainfall is reported, resulting in the flooding of numerous roads. The [[Coast Guard]] station in [[Ocean City, Maryland|Ocean City]] records a wind gust of {{convert|77|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} which results in several downed trees and power lines. The winds break loose a {{convert|160|ft|m|abbr=on}} [[barge]] from its moorings.<ref>{{cite web|author=National Climatic Data Center|title=Tropical Storm Josephine Event Report for Maryland|year=1996|publisher=|accessdate=2008-05-04|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~260311|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110520010211/http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~260311|archivedate=2011-05-20|df=}}</ref> * July 24, 1997 – [[Hurricane Danny (1997)|Tropical Storm Danny]] passes south of the state, dropping up to {{Convert|5|in|mm|abbr=on}} in southernmost locations.<ref>{{cite web|author=David Roth|title=Rainfall Summary for Hurricane Danny|year=1997|publisher=Hydromteorological Prediction Center|accessdate=2008-05-04|url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/tropical/rain//danny1997.html}}</ref> Because of a previous [[drought]], there are no reports of flooding except for minor drainage ditch overflows.<ref>{{cite web|author=National Climatic Data Center|title=Hurricane Danny Event Report for Maryland|year=1997|publisher=|accessdate=2008-05-04|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~291364|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110520010517/http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~291364|archivedate=2011-05-20|df=}}</ref> * August 5, 1998 – The remnants of [[Hurricane Earl (1998)|Hurricane Earl]] track south of the state, producing light rainfall on the [[Delmarva Peninsula]].<ref name="Mid Atl"/> * August 28, 1998 – [[Assateague Island]] reports {{convert|2.37|in|mm|abbr=on}} of rainfall from [[Hurricane Bonnie (1998)|Hurricane Bonnie]] which tracks offshore in the [[Atlantic]].<ref name="Mid Atl"/> * September 4, 1999 – The remnants of [[Hurricane Dennis (1999)|Hurricane Dennis]] drop heavy rainfall which surpasses {{convert|4|in|mm|abbr=on}} and flooding.<ref name="Mid Atl"/> On the coast of Maryland, tides were up to {{convert|3|ft|m|abbr=on}} above average.<ref name="dennis99">{{cite web|author=National Climatic Data Center|title=Hurricane Dennis Event Report for Maryland|year=1999|publisher=|accessdate=2008-05-04|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~359716|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110520010110/http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~359716|archivedate=2011-05-20|df=}}</ref> In [[Havre de Grace, Maryland|Havre de Grace]], four people were seriously injured when a car crossed the median and slammed into an oncoming vehicle, which is blamed on heavy rainfall.<ref>{{cite news|author1=David S. Fallis |author2=Linda Perlstein |lastauthoramp=yes|title=Dennis Rains More Trouble As It Fades |publisher=The Washington Post|accessdate=2008-05-04|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/local/daily/sept99/dennis090699.htm | date=1999-09-06}}</ref> Two or more lightning strikes leave over 6,700 people without power.<ref name="dennis99"/> [[Image:Floyd1999RadarPANYNJDMP.gif|right|200px|thumb|Rainfall from [[Hurricane Floyd]] affecting the state]] * September 15, 1999 – [[Hurricane Floyd]] parallels the shore of the Delmarva Peninsula as a tropical storm. [[Chestertown, Maryland|Chestertown]], reports a maximum rainfall total of 14 inches (350 mm), with other locales reporting similar values.<ref name="tcr">{{cite web |author=National Hurricane Center |year=1999 |title=Preliminary Report: Hurricane Floyd |publisher=NOAA |accessdate=2006-02-13 |url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/1999floyd.html |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101202095159/http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/1999floyd.html |archivedate=2010-12-02 |df= }}</ref> Extreme river flooding causes moderate damage to bridges and roads, resulting in a damage toll of $7.9 million (1999 USD, $10 million 2008 USD) throughout the state.<ref>{{cite web | year = 2000 | title = Hurricane Floyd Information: Maryland-Delaware-D.C. Area | publisher = USGS | accessdate = 2006-02-14 | url = http://md.water.usgs.gov/floods/floyd/damage.html}}</ref> In addition, over 250,000 residents are without [[electricity]] because of high winds blowing down power lines.<ref name="floyd">{{cite web|author=National Climatic Data Center|title=Hurricane Floyd Event Report for Maryland|year=1999|publisher=|accessdate=2008-05-04|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~359747|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110520010125/http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~359747|archivedate=2011-05-20|df=}}</ref> More than 28 people are forced to be rescued by [[boat]] as a result of severe flooding. Nine other people were from an apartment building near Great Mills. Two people are injured and one person is killed by [[carbon monoxide]] after losing power and running a generator inside their home. Also, a 12‑year-old boy is caught in [[flood]] waters and is swept a half mile (800 m) down a drainage ditch before being rescued and treated for [[hypothermia]].<ref name="floyd"/> * October 17, 1999 – Showers from [[Hurricane Irene (1999)|Hurricane Irene]] are reported, totaling to {{convert|1.29|in|mm|abbr=on}} in some places.<ref name="Mid Atl"/>
==2000–2004== * September 19, 2000 – The remnants of [[Hurricane Gordon (2000)|Hurricane Gordon]] track over the [[Delmarva Peninsula]], producing up to {{convert|2.17|in|mm|abbr=on}} of rainfall, mainly to the east of the center.<ref name="Mid Atl"/> * June 16, 2001 – The weakening [[Tropical Storm Allison]] tracks northward along the [[U.S. East Coast]], passing southeast of the state. Rainfall from Allison totaled to 7.5 inches (190 mm) in [[Denton, Maryland|Denton]], closing eleven roads and causing washouts on 41 others.<ref name="maryall">{{cite web|author=National Climatic Data Center |year=2001 |title=Tropical Storm Allison Event Report for Maryland |accessdate=2006-05-26 |url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~433132 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071222030855/http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~433132 |archivedate=2007-12-22 |df= }}</ref> * September 11, 2002 – The pressure gradient between a strong [[high pressure]] system in the central United States and [[Hurricane Gustav (2002)|Hurricane Gustav]] located east of the state result in gusty winds, peaking at {{convert|44|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} at [[Tolchester Beach, Maryland|Tolchester Beach]]. The winds damage tree limbs and caused power outages to 3,000 customers, although it was quickly restored.<ref>{{cite web|author=National Climatic Data Center|title=Hurricane Gustav Event Report for Maryland|year=2002|publisher=|accessdate=2008-05-04|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~461874|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110520010031/http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~461874|archivedate=2011-05-20|df=}}</ref> * September 16, 2002 – The remnants of [[Tropical Storm Hanna (2002)|Tropical Storm Hanna]] brought light rainfall to the [[Eastern Shore of Maryland|Eastern Shore]].<ref>{{cite web|author=David Roth|year=2002|title=Rainfall summary for Tropical Storm Hanna|publisher=Hydrometeorological Prediction Center|accessdate = 2017-01-15|url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/tropical/rain/hanna2002.html}}</ref> * September 27, 2002 – As the remnants of [[Hurricane Isidore]] track northward through the [[Ohio Valley]], it produces light to moderate showers in northern and central Maryland.<ref name="Mid Atl"/> * October 11, 2002—Remnant moisture from [[Hurricane Kyle (2002)|Hurricane Kyle]] produces moderate rainfall, reaching {{convert|4.03|in|mm|abbr=on}} in [[Salisbury, Maryland|Salisbury]].<ref name="Mid Atl"/> [[Image:Hurricane Isabel flood damage Maryland.jpg|right|thumb|Storm surge flooding caused by Isabel in [[Bowleys Quarters, Maryland]]]] * July 3, 2003 – Rainfall peaking at {{convert|4|in|mm|abbr=on}} falls in association with the remnants of [[Tropical Storm Bill (2003)|Tropical Storm Bill]].<ref>{{cite web|author=National Climatic Data Center|title=Tropical Storm Bill Event Report for Maryland|year=2003|publisher=|accessdate=2008-05-04|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~499352|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110520010039/http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~499352|archivedate=2011-05-20|df=}}</ref> In northern and central [[Dorchester County, Maryland|Dorchester County]], several secondary roads are closed due to heavy rainfall and flooding.<ref>{{cite web|author=National Climatic Data Center|title=Tropical Storm Bill Event Report for Maryland (2)|year=2003|publisher=|accessdate=2008-05-04|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~499354|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110520010043/http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~499354|archivedate=2011-05-20|df=}}</ref> * September 4, 2003 – The remnants of [[Tropical Storm Grace (2003)|Tropical Storm Grace]] drop up to {{convert|5|in|mm|abbr=on}} of rain in western areas of the state, although there are no reports of damage.<ref>{{cite web|author=David Roth|title=Rainfall Summary for Tropical Storm Grace|year=2003|publisher=Hydrometeorological Prediction Center|accessdate=2008-05-04|url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/tropical/rain//grace2003.html}}</ref> * September 14, 2003 – The remnant moisture from [[Tropical Storm Henri (2003)|Tropical Storm Henri]] produce light rainfall over the state.<ref>{{cite web|author=David Roth|year=2006|title=Rainfall information on Tropical Storm Henri|publisher=Hydrometeorological Prediction Center|accessdate = 2006-06-12|url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/tropical/rain/henri2003.html}}</ref> * September 17, 2003 – [[Hurricane Isabel]] tracks south and west of the state, causing [[Effects of Hurricane Isabel in Maryland|moderate to severe damage]]. Along the Eastern Shore, the hurricane produces a [[storm surge]] peaking at 8 feet (2.4 m) on the [[Chesapeake Bay]] side in [[List of islands in Maryland|Hoopers Island]] and 6.5 feet (2 m) on the Atlantic coast in [[Ocean City, Maryland|Ocean City]].<ref name="wakefield">{{cite web|author=Wakefield, Virginia National Weather Service |year=2003 |title=Hurricane Isabel Preliminary Storm Report |accessdate=2006-12-27 |url=http://www.erh.noaa.gov/akq/wx_events/hur/isabel_2003.htm |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050426064516/http://www.erh.noaa.gov/akq/wx_events/hur/isabel_2003.htm |archivedate=2005-04-26 |df= }}</ref> The large size of Isabel causes strong winds across the area, including maximum sustained winds of 52 mph (84 km/h) and a gust of 66 mph (106 km/h) in [[Cambridge, Maryland|Cambridge]].<ref name="wakefield"/> Over 1.4 million people throughout the state lose electric power at some point during the storm.<ref name="isabel">{{cite web|author=National Climatic Data Center|title=Hurricane Isabel Event Report for Maryland|year=2003|publisher=|accessdate=2008-05-04|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~499561|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110520010055/http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~499561|archivedate=2011-05-20|df=}}</ref> One death in Maryland is attributed to the hurricane, and over 200 injuries are reported. In all, damage is estimated at over $530 million (2003 USD, $621 million 2008 USD).<ref name="isabel"/> Winds sensors in [[Washington, D.C.]] report winds of up to {{convert|85|mph|km/h|abbr=on}}, which causes $125 million (2003 USD, $146 million 2008 USD) in damage.<ref>{{cite web|author=National Climatic Data Center|title=Hurricane Isabel Event Report for Washington D.C.|year=2003|publisher=|accessdate=2008-05-06|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~489093|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110520010805/http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~489093|archivedate=2011-05-20|df=}}</ref> * August 3, 2004 – [[Hurricane Alex (2004)|Hurricane Alex]]'s outskirts affected several portions of the state with heavy rainfall.<ref>{{cite web|author=David Roth|year=2004|title=Rainfall summary for Hurricane Alex|publisher=Hydrometeorological Prediction Center|accessdate = 2017-01-15|url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/tropical/rain/alex2004.html}}</ref> 6.05 in (154 mm) of rainfall was reported in [[Assateague Island]].<ref name="Mid Atl"/> * August 12, 2004 – Remnant moisture from [[Tropical Storm Bonnie (2004)|Tropical Storm Bonnie]] drops light rainfall across portions of the state.<ref name="Mid Atl"/> * August 14, 2004 – The weakening [[Hurricane Charley|Tropical Storm Charley]] drops rainfall across portions of the state.<ref>{{cite web|author=David Roth|year=2004|title=Rainfall summary for Hurricane Charley|publisher=Hydrometeorological Prediction Center|accessdate = 2017-01-15|url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/tropical/rain/charley2004.html}}</ref> In Assateague Island, total rainfall was reported at 2.21 in (56 mm).<ref name="Mid Atl"/> * August 30, 2004 – [[Hurricane Gaston (2004)|Hurricane Gaston]] tracks east of the state, producing light rainfall along the eastern shore.<ref name="Mid Atl"/> * September 3, 2004 – The remnants of [[Hurricane Frances]] produce over {{convert|6|in|mm|abbr=on}} of rain in some locations, although there are no reports of damage.<ref name="Mid Atl"/> * September 19, 2004 – The remnants of [[Hurricane Ivan]] drop up to {{convert|3.83|in|mm|abbr=on}} of rainfall, particularly in western areas.<ref name="Mid Atl"/> The system also results in several tornadoes, one of which is reported to have killed an elderly woman and her daughter when a tree fell on their home in [[Cecil County, Maryland|Cecil County]].<ref>{{cite news|author=The Washington Times|title=Maryland women die in Ivan's wake|year=2004|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author1=Lyndsey Layton |author2=Jamie Stockwell |lastauthoramp=yes|title=Tornado Damage Scattered, Severe; Residents Clean Up After Ivan Kills Two,<br /> Destroys Homes and Businesses in Va., Md.|year=2004|publisher=The Washington Post}}</ref> * September 28, 2004 – The remnants of [[Hurricane Jeanne]] spawn a [[waterspout]] which moves ashore as a tornado and damages a visitor center, tearing part of the roof off the structure and landing it on [[Maryland Route 2]]. The hurricane drops up to {{convert|4|in|mm|abbr=on}} of rainfall which results in widespread minor to moderate flooding.<ref name="Mid Atl"/> In total over 50 roads were closed due to flooding, and a group of inmates were rescued from the roof of a security van.<ref>{{cite web|author=National Climatic Data Center|title=Hurricane Jeanne Event Report for Maryland|year=2004|publisher=|accessdate=2008-05-03|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~539698|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110520005952/http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~539698|archivedate=2011-05-20|df=}}</ref>
==2005–2009== * July 8, 2005 – The [[extratropical cyclone|extratropical]] remnants of [[Hurricane Cindy (2005)|Hurricane Cindy]] drop upwards of {{convert|7|in|mm|abbr=on}} in the state,<ref>{{cite web|author=David Roth|title=Rainfall Summary for Hurricane Cindy|year=2005|publisher=Hydrometeorological Prediction Center|accessdate=2008-05-03|url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/tropical/rain//cindy2005.html}}</ref> and spawn one [[tornado]].<ref name="cindytcr">{{cite web|author=Stacy R. Stewart|title=Tropical Cyclone Report: Hurricane Cindy|year=2005|publisher=National Hurricane Center|accessdate=2008-05-03|url={{NHC TCR url|id=AL032005_Cindy}}}}</ref> which causes sporadic tree damage.<ref>{{cite web|author=National Climatic Data Center|title=Hurricane Cindy Event Report for Maryland|year=2005|publisher=|accessdate=2008-05-03|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~577985|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110520005906/http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~577985|archivedate=2011-05-20|df=}}</ref> The rainfall causes flooding in some locations, leaving numerous roads underwater,<ref>{{cite web|author=National Climatic Data Center|title=Hurricane Cindy Event Report for Maryland (2)|year=2005|publisher=|accessdate=2008-05-03|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~577987|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110520005911/http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~577987|archivedate=2011-05-20|df=}}</ref> and flooding several basements.<ref>{{cite web|author=National Climatic Data Center|title=Hurricane Cindy Event Report for Maryland (3)|year=2005|publisher=|accessdate=2008-05-03|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~577995|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110520005932/http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~577995|archivedate=2011-05-20|df=}}</ref> * July 9, 2005 – The remnants of [[Hurricane Dennis]] produce widespread light rainfall across much of the state.<ref>{{cite web|author=David Roth|title=Rainfall Summary for Hurricane Dennis|year=2005|publisher=Hydrometeorological Prediction Center|accessdate=2008-05-03|url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/tropical/rain//dennis2005.html}}</ref> * August 31, 2005 – The remnants of [[Hurricane Katrina]] produce light rainfall across western portions of the state. Rainfall peaked at 2.30 in (58 mm) in [[Thurmont, Maryland|Thurmont]].<ref>{{cite web|author=Weather Preictions Center|title=Remnants of KATRINA Advisory Number 37|year=2005|publisher=NOAA|accessdate=2017-04-21|url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/tropical/tropical_advisories.php?storm=KATRINA&adnum=37&dt=2005090103&status=remnants}}</ref> * October 8, 2005 – A combination of the remnants of [[Tropical Storm Tammy (2005)|Tropical Storm Tammy]] and [[List of storms in the 2005 Atlantic hurricane season#Subtropical Depression Twenty-two|Subtropical Depression Twenty-Two]] contribute to the [[Northeast U.S. flooding of October 2005]], which produces up to {{convert|9|in|mm|abbr=on}} of rainfall.<ref>{{cite web|author=Scott Stephens|title=Hazards/Climate Extremes|year=200|publisher=NOAA/NCDC|accessdate=2008-05-03|url=http://www.ncdc.noaa.gov/oa/climate/research/2005/oct/hazards.html#Flooding}}</ref> Dozens of roads are flooded and closed, and about 30 people are forced from their homes. Flood waters reach up to {{convert|6|ft|m|abbr=on}} as reported by a local newspaper. Damage is estimated at $200,000 (2005 USD, $220,000 2008 USD).<ref>{{cite web|author=National Climatic Data Center|title=Flooding Report for Maryland|accessdate=2008-05-03|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~578066|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110520005948/http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~578066|archivedate=2011-05-20|df=}}</ref> * October 24, 2005 – A nor'easter fed by [[Hurricane Wilma]] brought heavy rain, wind, and snow to the state. Dozens of schools were closed and 12 inches of snow fell in western Maryland.<ref>{{Cite news|title=Nor'easter Dumps Early Snow|year=2005|work=The Associated Press|publisher=Fox News}}</ref> * June 14, 2006—The remnants of [[Tropical Storm Alberto (2006)|Tropical Storm Alberto]] drop light rainfall in southern locations.<ref name="Mid Atl"/> * September 1–2, 2006 – High winds and heavy rainfall from [[Hurricane Ernesto (2006)|Hurricane Ernesto]] leaves 44,000 homes without electric power, mostly in low-lying areas of southern locations and on the eastern shore. Several basements in [[Anne Arundel County, Maryland|Anne Arundel County]] are forced to be pumped out due to flooding. It is estimated that wind gusts peaked at {{convert|50|mph|km/h|abbr=on}}.<ref>{{Cite news|author1=Stephanie Desmon |author2=Gadi Dechte |lastauthoramp=yes|title=Ernesto's wind gusts punched away at Md.|year=2006|publisher=Baltimore Sun}}</ref> * June 3, 2007 – [[Tropical Storm Barry (2007)|Tropical Storm Barry]] produces light rainfall over eastern portions of the state, peaking at {{convert|2.30|in|mm|abbr=on}} near [[Columbia, Maryland|Columbia]].{{Tropical Cyclone Rainfall in the Mid Atlantic United States}} * September 15, 2007 – The remnants of [[Hurricane Humberto (2007)|Hurricane Humberto]] drop light rainfall in extreme southern locations.<ref>{{cite web|author=David Roth|title=Rainfall Summary for Hurricane Humberto|year=2007|publisher=Hydrometeorological Prediction Center|accessdate=2008-05-03|url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/tropical/rain//humberto2007.html}}</ref> * August 28, 2008 – The remnants of [[Tropical Storm Fay (2008)|Tropical Storm Fay]] brought light rainfall to extreme western portions of the state.<ref>{{cite web|author=David Roth|title=Rainfall Summary for Tropical Storm Fay|year=2008|publisher=Hydrometeorological Prediction Center|accessdate=2017-01-15|url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/tropical/rain/fay2008.html}}</ref> 2.98 in (75 mm) of rainfall was reported in [[Pinto, Maryland|Pinto]].<ref name="Mid Atl"/> * September 6, 2008 – [[Tropical Storm Hanna (2008)|Tropical Storm Hanna]] moved over the area from the south, dropping over 4 inches of rain in parts of Maryland and producing wind gusts to 50 MPH in Southern Maryland.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2008/09/06/AR2008090603047.html|title=Heavy Rain Forces Evacuations, Causes Floods Across Area|last=Miroff|first=Nick|author2=Rucker, Phillip |author3=Fahrenthold David A. |date=2008-09-07|work=The Washington Post|accessdate=2009-08-19}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.erh.noaa.gov/er/lwx/events/hanna2008/pns.php |title=NWS Sterling — Tropical Storm Hanna Gusts and Rainfall |publisher=Erh.noaa.gov |accessdate=2010-03-24}}</ref> * November 10–14, 2009 – The remnants of [[Hurricane Ida]] contribute to the emergence of an [[extratropical cyclone]] that brought heavy rainfall and gusty winds to the state.<ref>{{cite web|author=Lixion A. Avila and John Cangialosi|title=Hurricane Ida Tropical Cyclone Report|year=2009|publisher=National Hurricane Center|accessdate=2017-01-11|url={{NHC TCR url|id=AL112009_Ida}}|format=PDF}}</ref> 7.40 in (188 mm) of rain fell in [[Assateague Island]].<ref name="Mid Atl"/> This storm would later be known as the [[November 2009 Mid-Atlantic nor'easter]].
==2010–2014== * September 3, 2010 – [[Hurricane Earl (2010)|Hurricane Earl]] skimmed the coast of [[North Carolina]] and moved northeastward, resulting in heavy rain and tropical storm force winds in Southeastern Maryland, near [[Ocean City, Maryland|Ocean City]]. Areas inland were not affected by Earl. * September 30, 2010 – The remnants of [[Tropical Storm Nicole (2010)|Tropical Storm Nicole]] produced massive amounts of rainfall across the state. [[Baltimore–Washington International Airport]] reported 6.02 in (153 mm) of total rainfall in 24 hours.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/hurricanes/archives/2010/h2010_Nicole.html|author1=Rob Gutro|title=Hurricane Season 2010: Tropical Storm Nicole (Atlantic Ocean)|work=NASA|accessdate=2017-01-11}}</ref> Two transit buses collided during the storm, injuring 26 people.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.syracuse.com/news/index.ssf/2010/09/massive_storms_blamed_for_4_de.html|agency=Associated Press|publisher=Syracuse|title=Massive storms blamed for 4 deaths in the East Coast|date=2010|accessdate=2017-01-11}}</ref> * August 27, 2011 – [[Hurricane Irene (2011)|Hurricane Irene]] did not make direct landfall, but due to the large size, hurricane conditions were felt to the east of the [[Chesapeake Bay]] and tropical storm conditions were felt as far inland as [[Frederick, MD]]. Along the Delmarva Peninsula, sustained winds of 60 mph with gusts up to 85 mph and over a foot of rain fell over the area. There was also a five-foot storm surge that inundated regions around [[Ocean City, MD]]. The beach was evacuated prior to the storm; due to the minimal damage, it reopened the next day on Sunday and residents and tourists were allowed to return.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ibtimes.com/articles/205488/20110829/hurricane-irene-ocean-city-maryland.htm|title=Hurricane Irene: Ocean City, Md. Resort ‘Dodges Missile’|work=IB Times|accessdate=2017-01-03}}</ref> In Central Maryland, sustained winds of 30-40 mph and 3-5 inches of rain fell. Gusts of up to 65 mph toppled many power lines. Most of the damage was from falling trees, which blocked roads, crushed power lines, and toppled onto houses. Power was out for over 200,000 people in Maryland; however, by Sunday, most power was restored.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/08/29/us-storm-irene-maryland-dc-idUSTRE77S3CT20110829?feedType=RSS&feedName=domesticNews|work=Reuters|title=Post-Irene power, transport problems linger in MD, D.C|accessdate=2017-01-03}}</ref> * September 7–10, 2011 – The remnants of [[Tropical Storm Lee (2011)|Tropical Storm Lee]] move across Maryland, causing widespread flooding, particularly in the western portion of the state.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://articles.baltimoresun.com/2011-09-08/news/bs-md-river-floods-20110908_1_cause-flooding-standing-water-rescue-team|title=Heavy rains cause flooding around Maryland|author1=Frank D. Roylance |author2=Jessica Anderson |lastauthoramp=yes|date=2011|newspaper=The Baltimore Sun|accessdate=2016-05-14}}</ref> In combination with Hurricane Irene, The National Weather Service reported rainfall totals in [[Prince George's County]] at 24.13 in (613 mm) in [[Largo, Maryland|Largo]], 23.98 in (609 mm) in [[Forestville, Maryland|Forestville]], and 21.49 in (546 mm) in [[Forest Heights, Maryland|Forest Heights]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/dc-areas-recent-rainfall-might-be-once-in-a-thousand-years-event/2011/09/16/gIQAtU1qYK_story.html|work=The Washington Post|first=Martin|last=Weil|date=2011|title=D.C. area's recent rainfall might be once-in-a-thousand-years event|accessdate=2017-01-11}}</ref> * September 1–3, 2012 – The remnants of [[Hurricane Isaac (2012)|Hurricane Isaac]] brought light rainfall to the state.<ref>{{cite web|author=David Roth|title=Rainfall Summary for Hurricane Isaac|year=2012|publisher=Hydrometeorological Prediction Center|accessdate=2017-01-11|url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/tropical/rain/isaac2012.html}}</ref> * October 29, 2012 – [[Hurricane Sandy]] makes landfall north of the state. However, due to the tremendous size of the storm, its effects were felt all over Maryland. During the peak of the storm, 60 mph sustained winds were felt from Frederick, Maryland eastward. However, power outages were not widespread and any problems were solved quickly due to better preparation. Heavy rain affected the state, with up to a foot of rain falling in some spots. Storm surge was also a large factor along the beaches, washing out many piers and some boardwalks along [[Ocean City, Maryland|Ocean City]]. Hurricane Sandy is the deadliest tropical cyclone to affect the state, causing 11 deaths.<ref>{{cite web|title=Sandy death toll in US rises to 109; 'there could be more,' Bloomberg warns|url=http://usnews.nbcnews.com/_news/2012/11/02/14884300-sandy-death-toll-in-us-rises-to-109-there-could-be-more-bloomberg-warns?lite|publisher=NBC News|accessdate=2016-05-31|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160313204453/http://usnews.nbcnews.com/_news/2012/11/02/14884300-sandy-death-toll-in-us-rises-to-109-there-could-be-more-bloomberg-warns?lite|archivedate=2016-03-13|df=}}</ref> * June 7, 2013 – Rain bands from [[Tropical Storm Andrea (2013)|Tropical Storm Andrea]] cause minor flooding in the [[Baltimore-Washington metropolitan area|Baltimore-Washington area]] and parts of the [[Eastern Shore of Maryland|Eastern Shore]], with rainfall totals of just over 2 in (51 mm) in [[Annapolis, Maryland|Annapolis]] and [[Baltimore-Washington International Airport]], both in [[Anne Arundel County, Maryland|Anne Arundel County]]. Andrea was a post-tropical system by the time the center moved over [[St. Mary's County, Maryland|St. Mary's County]] and the lower Eastern Shore, which was under a [[tornado watch]] at the time due to the system's history of producing tornadoes.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://articles.baltimoresun.com/2013-06-07/news/bal-wx-tropical-storm-andrea-forecast-to-bring-heavy-rains-friday-20130606_1_chance-rain-cecil-county|title=Andrea, no longer tropical, dumping heavy rains Friday|author1=Scott Dance|lastauthoramp=yes|date=2013|newspaper=The Baltimore Sun|accessdate=2017-01-03}}</ref> * October 9–12, 2013 – The remnants of [[Tropical Storm Karen (2013)|Tropical Storm Karen]] brought heavy rainfall to the state.<ref>{{cite web|author=David Roth|title=Rainfall Summary for Tropical Storm Karen|year=2013|publisher=Hydrometeorological Prediction Center|accessdate=2017-01-11|url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/tropical/rain/karen2013.html}}</ref> * July 4, 2014 – [[Hurricane Arthur (2014)|Hurricane Arthur]]'s outskirts brought heavy rain and wind gusts in excess of 40 mph to areas such as [[Ocean City, Maryland|Ocean City]] and [[Salisbury, Maryland|Salisbury]]. Areas further inland were not impacted by the storm.<ref>{{cite report|author=Robbie J. Berg|title=Tropical Cyclone Report: Hurricane Arthur|url={{NHC TCR url|id=AL012014_Arthur}}|publisher=National Hurricane Center|date=2015|accessdate=2016-05-31|page=21|location=Miami, Florida|format=PDF}}</ref> * August 28, 2014 – [[Hurricane Cristobal]] passes offshore, killing a swimmer in [[Ocean City, Maryland|Ocean City]]. The [[Coast Guard]] also rescued three people after their 17-foot boat overturned.<ref>{{cite news|author=Scott Dance|date=2014|newspaper=The Baltimore Sun|accessdate=2017-01-11|title=Swimming restrictions in place in Ocean City as Cristobal stirs up seas, drowning Va. teen|url=http://articles.baltimoresun.com/2014-08-28/travel/bs-md-ocean-city-drowning-20140827_1_ocean-city-beach-patrol-high-waves-first-summer}}</ref> * September 17, 2014 – [[2014 Atlantic hurricane season#Hurricane Edouard|Hurricane Edouard]] passes well offshore, but strong rip currents result in two deaths off the coast of [[Ocean City, Maryland|Ocean City]].<ref>{{cite web|publisher=NBC4 Washington|date=2014|accessdate=2017-01-23|title=Strong Rip Currents Kill Two Men in Ocean City|url=http://www.nbcwashington.com/news/local/Strong-Rip-Currents-Kill-Two-Men-in-Ocean-City-275640531.html}}</ref>
==2015–present== * May 11, 2015 – [[Tropical Storm Ana (2015)|Tropical Storm Ana]] skimmed the [[Eastern Shore of Maryland|Eastern Shore]] and brought gentle light rainfall to the area.<ref>{{cite report|author=Stacy Stewart|title=Tropical Cyclone Report: Tropical Storm Ana|url={{NHC TCR url|id=AL012015_Ana}}|publisher=National Hurricane Center|date=2015|accessdate=2016-05-31|pages=2, 3|location=Miami, Florida|format=PDF}}</ref> * June 20, 2015 – The remnants of [[Tropical Storm Bill (2015)|Tropical Storm Bill]] brought heavy rainfall, thunderstorms, and gusty winds to the state. A tornado touched down in [[Tuscarora, Maryland|Tuscarora]], but caused no damage.<ref name="spc620">{{cite web|url=http://www.spc.noaa.gov/climo/reports/150620_rpts.html|title=20150620's Storm Reports|date=2015|work=Storm Prediction Center|publisher=National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration|accessdate=2016-05-14|location=Norman, Oklahoma}}</ref> * October 28, 2015 – The remnants of [[Hurricane Patricia]] brought rainfall to western portions of the state.<ref>{{cite web|author=David Roth|title=Rainfall Summary for Hurricane Patricia|year=2015|publisher=Hydrometeorological Prediction Center|accessdate=2017-05-16|url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/tropical/rain/patricia2015filledrainwhite.gif}}</ref> * May 29–30, 2016 – Tropical moisture from [[Tropical Storm Bonnie (2016)|Tropical Storm Bonnie]] brought widespread rainfall across the state.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/text/refresh/MIAWPCAT2+shtml/310858.shtml|title=Post Tropical Cyclone BONNIE Public Advisory|accessdate=2016-05-31}}</ref> * September 3, 2016 – [[Tropical Storm Hermine (2016)|Tropical Storm Hermine]] affected the majority of the Eastern Shore with heavy rainfall and high winds, prompting tropical storm warnings to be put up. Governor [[Larry Hogan]] also declared a state of emergency for several counties along the Eastern Shore.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://governor.maryland.gov/2016/09/02/governor-larry-hogan-signs-executive-order-declaring-state-of-emergency-for-eastern-shore-southern-maryland/|title=Governor Larry Hogan Signs Executive Order Declaring State of Emergency for Eastern Shore, Southern Maryland|accessdate=2016-09-04}}</ref> Winds gusted well over 40 mph in [[Ocean City, Maryland]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.delmarvanow.com/story/news/local/maryland/2016/09/03/ocean-city-hermine-tourists-worcester-storm/89835264/|author1=Deborah Gates|title=Hogan warns travelers to OC as Hermine travels through|work=DelmarvaNow|accessdate=2016-09-04}}</ref> * September 19–22, 2016 – A combination of the remnants of [[Tropical Storm Julia (2016)|Tropical Storm Julia]] and a cold front brought rainfall to the state.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nasa.gov/feature/goddard/2016/julia-atlantic-ocean|author1=Rob Gutro|title=Post-Tropical Cyclone Julia Mixing With Cold Front Along U.S. East Coast|work=NASA|accessdate=2017-01-07}}</ref> * October 8–9, 2016 – While [[Hurricane Matthew]] did not make landfall in the state, the storm still brought rain and gusty winds to the state due to its large size.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.delmarvanow.com/story/news/local/maryland/2016/10/09/maryland-delmarva-hurricane-matthew/91822496/|author1=Jeremy Cox|title=Wicomico, Somerset and Va. soaked by Hurricane Matthew|work=DelmarvaNow|accessdate=2017-01-03}}</ref> A maximum rainfall total of 5.52 in (140 mm) was reported in [[Berlin, Maryland|Berlin]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ecowatch.com/hurricane-matthew-death-toll-2037803913.html|work=EcoWatch|author1=Jeff Masters|author2=Bob Henson|lastauthoramp=yes|date=2016|title=After 12-Day Rampage, Hurricane Matthew Leaves More Than 1,000 Dead|accessdate=2017-01-11}}</ref> A wind gust of 49 mph was reported in Ocean City as well.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/capital-weather-gang/wp/2016/10/11/horrific-rains-and-ocean-surge-hurricane-matthew-by-the-numbers/|work=The Washington Post|author1=Jason Samenow|author2=Angela Fritz|lastauthoramp=yes|date=2016|title=Horrific rains and ocean surge: Hurricane Matthew by the numbers|accessdate=2017-01-11}}</ref> * June 23–24, 2017 – The remnants of [[Tropical Storm Cindy (2017)|Tropical Storm Cindy]] brought rainfall to the entire state.{{citation needed|date=September 2018}} * September 2, 2017 – The remnants of [[Hurricane Harvey]] brought heavy rain, thunderstorms and gusty winds to the state.{{citation needed|date=September 2018}} * September 19, 2017 – [[Hurricane Jose (2017)|Hurricane Jose]] passes offshore, which brought showers, gusty winds and high rip currents to the Eastern Shore.{{citation needed|date=September 2018}} * October 29, 2017 – [[2017 Atlantic Hurricane Season#Tropical Storm Philippe|Tropical Storm Philippe]] is absorbed by a non-tropical area of low pressure, which brought heavy rainfall and high winds to the state. Snow also fell in extreme western portions.{{citation needed|date=September 2018}} * September 8, 2018 – The remnants of [[Tropical Storm Gordon (2018)|Tropical Storm Gordon]] are absorbed by a large [[Weather front|front]]. The new system brings rainfall on the state for several days.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://earth.nullschool.net/#2018/09/09/0300Z/wind/isobaric/850hPa/orthographic=-75.96,34.46,1090/loc=-71.424,38.682|title=earth 2️⃣ a global map of wind, weather, and ocean conditions|work=earth.nullschool.net|accessdate=2018-09-15}}</ref> * September 14, 2018 – [[Hurricane Florence]] tracks south of the state, with its outer bands bringing rain and gusty winds to the state.{{citation needed|date=September 2018}} * October 11–12, 2018 – [[Hurricane Michael|Tropical Storm Michael]] tracks inland, bringing heavy rainfall and gusty winds to the state.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.delmarvanow.com/story/news/2018/10/12/tropical-storm-michael-wind-damage-and-flooding/1612021002/|title=Tropical Storm Michael: A trail of wind damage and flooding|work=Delmarva Daily Times|access-date=2018-10-12|language=en}}</ref> *October 26–27, 2018 – The remnants of [[Hurricane Willa]] brought rainfall and gusty winds to much of the state.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.baltimoresun.com/news/weather/bs-md-willa-east-coast-storm-20181022-story.html|title=Remnants of Hurricane Willa could bring rain, wind and mountain snow to Maryland this weekend|last=Dance|first=Scott|work=baltimoresun.com|access-date=2018-10-27|language=en-US}}</ref>

page.title: List of meteorological histories of tropical cyclones

revision.text:
[[File:Hurricane Gustav 30 Aug 2008 1605z.jpg|thumb|right|260px|[[Hurricane Gustav]] at peak intensity on August 29, 2008.]]
This page documents the list of '''meteorological histories of tropical cyclones'''. These storms have detailed information on their respective histories as [[tropical cyclone]]s, including formation, peak intensity, dissipation, and other notable facts the storm was known for.
==1990s== ===Atlantic=== *[[Meteorological history of Hurricane Andrew|Hurricane Andrew]] (1992) – the last [[List of Category 5 Atlantic hurricanes|Category 5]] hurricane to strike the [[United States]], and at the time was the costliest tropical cyclone known, with over $20 billion in damages. *[[Meteorological history of Hurricane Gordon (1994)|Hurricane Gordon (1994)]] – a long-lived tropical cyclone which took an unusual track off the Southeast United States, while also displaying hybrid characteristics at times.<ref name="tcr">{{cite web|author=Richard Pasch|year=1995|title=Hurricane Gordon Preliminary Report|publisher=National Hurricane Center|accessdate=2007-10-04|url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/1994gordon.html}}</ref> *[[Meteorological history of Hurricane Luis|Hurricane Luis]] (1995) – Powerful category 4 [[Cape Verde hurricane]] which severely impacted the Windward Islands.<ref name="TCR2">{{cite web|author=Miles B. Lawrence|title=Hurricane Luis Preliminary Report|date=January 8, 1996|publisher=National Hurricane Center|accessdate=2016-11-29|url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/data/tcr/AL131995_Luis.pdf}}</ref> *[[Meteorological history of Hurricane Georges|Hurricane Georges]] (1998) – long-lived tropical cyclone which impacted areas from the [[Windward Islands]] all the way to the [[Southeastern United States]]. *[[Meteorological history of Hurricane Mitch|Hurricane Mitch]] (1998) – The second-deadliest [[Atlantic hurricane]] ever recorded, with over 12,000 deaths. Peaked as a powerful Category 5 in the [[Caribbean Sea]].<ref name="nhc">{{cite report|author=John L. Guiney|author2=Miles B. Lawrence|publisher=National Hurricane Center|date=1999-01-28|title=Hurricane Mitch Preliminary Report|accessdate=2013-05-12|url={{NHC TCR url|id=AL131998_Mitch}}|format=PDF}}</ref>
[[File:Andrew 1992 track.png|thumb|right|200px|Track of [[Hurricane Andrew]] in 1992.]]
==2000s==
===Atlantic=== *[[Meteorological history of Hurricane Ivan|Hurricane Ivan]] (2004) – Long-tracked Cape Verde hurricane which peaked 3 times as a Category 5, struck the [[Florida Panhandle]] as a Category 3. Made a large clockwise loop over the Eastern United States and regenerated in the [[Gulf of Mexico]].<ref name="TCR">{{cite web |url={{NHC TCR url |id= AL092004_Ivan}} |title=Hurricane Ivan Tropical Cyclone Report |last=Stewart |first=Stacey |date= May 22, 2005|publisher=[[National Hurricane Center]] |accessdate= August 20, 2010 }}</ref> *[[Meteorological history of Hurricane Jeanne|Hurricane Jeanne]] (2004) – another hurricane that struck Florida after impacting [[Haiti]], [[Cuba]] and the [[Bahamas]]. *[[Meteorological history of Hurricane Dennis|Hurricane Dennis]] (2005) – High-end Category 4 hurricane which caused destruction throughout its path from Haiti all the way to the [[Gulf Coast]]. It was the first of many powerful hurricanes to strike the coastline in 2005. *[[Meteorological history of Hurricane Katrina|Hurricane Katrina]] (2005) – The costliest natural disaster ever recorded, with totals exceeding $100 billion damages. Struck the Louisiana–Mississippi region on August 29 as a major hurricane, [[Effects of Hurricane Katrina in New Orleans|causing major damage in New Orleans]] and other surrounding areas. *[[Meteorological history of Hurricane Wilma|Hurricane Wilma]] (2005) – The [[List of most intense tropical cyclones|most intense hurricane ever recorded in the Atlantic]], with a minimum pressure of {{convert|882|mbar|inHg}}. Was also the last recent major hurricane to strike the United States until Hurricane Harvey in 2017. *[[Meteorological history of Hurricane Dean|Hurricane Dean]] (2007) – Classic long-tracked Cape Verde hurricane which is tied for the third-most intense landfalling hurricane in the Atlantic, striking the [[Yucatán Peninsula]] as a Category 5 with maximum sustained winds of {{convert|175|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} and a central pressure of {{convert|905|mbar|inHg}}. *[[Meteorological history of Hurricane Gustav|Hurricane Gustav]] (2008) – Intense high-end Category 4 hurricane which impacted areas from [[Haiti]] to [[Louisiana]] in the United States around the [[Labor Day]] weekend.
===Southern Indian=== *[[Meteorological history of Cyclone Leon–Eline|Cyclone Leon–Eline]] (2000) – the longest-lived tropical cyclone in the South Indian Ocean. Struck southern [[Africa]] as a Category 4-equivalent tropical cyclone.
===Western Pacific===
*[[Meteorological history of Typhoon Durian|Typhoon Durian]] (2006) – Powerful super typhoon that devastated parts of the [[Philippines]] as a high-end Category 4-equivalent. Tracked southwest into [[South China Sea]] before crossing into the [[2006 North Indian Ocean cyclone season#Other systems|North Indian Ocean]] basin.
==2010s==
===Atlantic===
*[[Meteorological history of Hurricane Sandy|Hurricane Sandy]] (2012) – The second-most destructive and largest tropical cyclone recorded in the Atlantic. Struck Jamaica as a hurricane and Cuba as a major, before slamming the Bahamas and eventually morphing into an extremely large hybrid storm, before hooking left and slamming into the [[New Jersey]] coastline on October 29, causing tremendous damage.
*[[Meteorological history of Hurricane Matthew|Hurricane Matthew]] (2016) – Long-lived hurricane which was the first [[List of Category 5 Atlantic hurricanes|Category 5]] in the Atlantic since [[Hurricane Felix]] in 2007. Tore through the Caribbean and devastated [[Haiti]] on October 4 before passing through the Bahamas and paralleling the Florida coast as a Category 4. Made landfall as a Category 1 in the United States early on October 8.
*[[Meteorological history of Hurricane Harvey|Hurricane Harvey]] (2017)
*[[Meteorological history of Hurricane Irma|Hurricane Irma]] (2017)
*[[Meteorological history of Hurricane Maria|Hurricane Maria]] (2017)
===Eastern Pacific=== [[File:Patricia 2015-10-23 1730Z (Worldview).jpg|thumb|right|200px|[[Hurricane Patricia]] at record peak intensity on October 23, 2015.]] *[[Meteorological history of Hurricane Patricia|Hurricane Patricia]] (2015) – The second-most intense tropical cyclone recorded worldwide in terms of minimum pressure, with a central pressure of {{convert|872|mbar|inHg}}, and the strongest worldwide in terms 1-minute sustained winds, which peaked at {{convert|215|mph|km/h|abbr=on}}. Also underwent one of the most explosive intensification periods known in history, growing from a tropical storm to a Category 5 hurricane in 24 hours, not to mention a near {{convert|100|mbar|inHg}} drop in just over 24 hours from October 22–23.
===Western Pacific===
*[[Meteorological history of Typhoon Haiyan|Typhoon Haiyan]] (2013) – One of the most intense tropical cyclones recorded and the most intense tropical cyclone to make landfall worldwide, with winds at landfall estimated to be around {{convert|195|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} in the [[Philippines]]. Caused massive devastation in the Philippines.
== See also == {{portal|Tropical cyclones}} * [[List of tropical cyclones]] * [[List of the most intense tropical cyclones]]
== References == {{reflist}}
